# Money chasing hot industries? Investor attention and valuation of venture capital backed firms  

Jiangjing Que ?, Xueyong Zhang  

Schoolof IntenationalEconomicsandManagementejingTechnologyandBusinessUniversity,BeijingChin b School of Finance, Central University of Finance and Economics, Bejing, China  

# ARTICLEINFO  

# ABSTRACT  

JEL classification:   
G24   
G32   
Keywords:   
Investor attention   
Venture capital   
Pre-money valuation  

This study analyzes how investor attention to industries affects firm valuations in the venture capital market. Relying on aggregate search frequency in Baidu, we construct a direct measure of investor attention to industries (AsVI). Our results show that an increase in AsVI predicts higher firm valuations. We prove that the price increase is an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium, which is due to the evidence of a long-run reversal of firm valuations and worse performance of vC investments. Our findings continue to hold across a wide range of robustness checks, including sample selection, endogeneity, alternative measures of ASVI. We also find that syndicated investments and involvement of experienced venture capitalists attenuate the effect of AsVI on firm valuations, further supporting the attention-induced view.  

## 1. Introduction  

The relationship between investor attention and asset pricing in public markets has been well explored by numerous studies in recent years (Baker and Wurgler, 2006; Fang and Peress, 2009; Da et al., 2011). However, there is a dearth of empirical work regarding the impact of investor attention on the pricing in the venture capital (VC) industry. The valuation of VC-backed firms determines cost of capital for entrepreneurs (i.e., the ownership stake they give up) and ultimate return for venture capitalists (i.e., the difference between exit proceeds and the amount they invested), which is therefore vitally important to both sides (Engel and Keilbach, 2007; Hochberg et al., 2010). Existing literature on the determinants of VC valuations includes firm characteristics (Hand, 2005; Hsu, 2007), venture capital characteristics (Cumming and Dai, 2011; Collwaert and Manigart, 2016) and market conditions (Gompers and Lerner, 2000). Unlike earlier studies, our paper examines how investor attention to industries, measured by aggregate search frequency in Baidu (Search Volume Index (SVI)), influences the valuation of VC-backed firms in China.  

Relying on a sample of 5621 financing rounds from 2006 to 2017, we find that firms in industries with an increase in investor attention exhibit higher valuations, which is shown to be an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium. Moreover, we find that syndication and involvement of experienced venture capitalists can reduce firm valuations, which provides further evidence for the view of attention-induced price increases. Our paper, as far as we know, presents the first empirical evidence on how investor attention impacts the pricing in the venture capital industry.  

There are three reasons why investor attention is measured at an industry level rather than at the firm level. First, venture capitalists, as human beings constrained by limited information processing capacity (Miller, 1956), are faced with the task of choosing among thousands of start-ups. This limited capacity leads investors to allocate more attention to sector-level factors (such as industries, locations or countries) than to firm-specific factors (Peng and Xiong, 2006). Furthermore, industry is an important component in a wide range of asset pricing phenomena (Cohen et al., 2003; Hou and Robinson, 2006; Hou, 2007). Therefore, venture capitalists tend to manage the vast amount of choices by limiting their search to certain industries, which prevents them from being overwhelmed by financing requests from a large number of start-ups (Odean, 1999; Ding et al., 2017).  

Second, when venture capitalists evaluate and invest in start-ups, they tend to specialize by industry and fund firms in industries they have experience (Sahlman, 1990; Barry et al., 1990; Kaplan and Stromberg, 2003). Long-standing experience in an industry could allow venture capitalists to better identify good investment opportunities and to know how to manage and add value to these investments (Gompers et al., 2008).  

Third, unlike public firms, private firms are largely exempt from disclosure requirements and thus lack of available data (Kaplan and Schoar, 2005), which leads individual investors to rarely search for firm-level information in Baidu. As a consequence, Baidu Index does not return a valid $\mathsf{s u l}^{1}$ for the large majority of private firms. This lack of SVI data would introduce systematic biases and fail to reflect the actual relationship between investor attention and firm valuations. Therefore, we choose industry as a proxy to measure investor attentionforthisstudy.  

We propose a direct measure of investor attention to an industry using aggregate search frequency in Baidu. We first define the abnormal SVI (△sVI) for an industry by calculating the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing minus the SVI during the previous 30 days, scaled by the SVI during the previous 30 days. To address the differences across industries and heteroscedasticity, we follow prior studies (Da et al., 2015; Gao et al., 2019) and construct our main variable, AsVI, by regressing △sVI on industry dummies, keeping the residuals, then normalizing these residuals using their standard deviations.  

Using the measure of AsVI, we investigate how investor attention to industries impacts the valuation of VC-backed firms. According to the attention theory (Ljungqvist et al., 2006; Barber and Odean, 2008; Da et al., 2011), an increase in individual investor attention drives up stock prices and IPO valuation, and eventually causes the long-run underperformance when investor attention dissipates. Consequently, we predict that firms with higher AsVI are offered higher valuations by venture capitalists and eventually exhibit worse performance when investor attention declines.  

Alternatively, fundamental theory argues that positive news about an industry's prospects also result in an increase in search frequency and further push up firm valuations. Inconsistent with the attention theory, if high valuations are rational responses to fundamental information about the changing prospects, investments should be more successful and exhibit better performance.  

To test our hypothesis, we first examine the relationship between AsVI and firm valuations. Our results show that an increase in ASVI during the 30 days prior to the financing predicts higher firm valuations. Considering that prices may be affected by differences between the first and later round investors (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Hand, 2005), we examine the results for the first financing rounds and later financing rounds (i.e., all non-first financing rounds) separately. The results suggest that the positive relationship between AsVI and firm valuations continues to hold for both the first and later financing rounds.  

We next distinguish the attention hypothesis and the fundamental hypothesis by examining the long-run performance of firm valuations following Da et al. (2011). Subject to data availability, we investigate the influence of AsVI in the current round on firm valuations in the subsequent round. Our results show that an increase in AsVI in the current round predicts a reversal in the next round. This evidence suggests that an increase in firm valuations is an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium.  

Another natural venue to test the attention theory is the performance of VC investments. The performance of VC investments is measured by the performance of successful exits of portfolio companies and exit return multiples of venture capital (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Hochberg et al., 2007). We find that firms with higher AsVI have a lower probability of successful exits and lower exit return multiples of venture capital, supporting the attention-induced view.  

In addition, a variety of diagnostic analyses are undertaken in our robustness tests. First, a substantial portion of financing rounds does not disclose valuation data, which may introduce systematic biases between rounds with and without valuation data (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Cumming and Dai, 2011). We use a Heckman selection approach to address this concern and find that our main results carry through with this alternative approach. Second, the omitted variable bias may lead to inflated values for the coefficients of correlated independent variables (Judge et al., 1985), which would cause us to falsely impute significance to the measure of investor attention to industries. To rule out this endogeneity, we employ an instrumental variable approach and our results persist in instrumental regression. Third, to address the concern that a 30-day window is insufficient to measure changes of investor attention, we construct AsVI using both 60-day and 90-day windows to reexamine the baseline analyses and find that our conclusions continue to hold.  

Finally, we examine the effect of syndication and involvement of experienced VCs on firm valuations. According to Cumming and Walz (2010) and Heughebaert and Manigart (2012), syndication and experience could help VCs alleviate information asymmetry and forecast firm valuations more precisely. Therefore, if an increase in firm valuations are driven by investor attention, this overvaluation could be reduced by these adjustments of investment strategies. We investigate the effect of syndicated investments and involvement of experienced VCs on firm valuations and find that both of them significantly attenuate the effect of investor attention on firm valuations, supporting the attention-induced view.  

Our study contributes to two strands of literature. First, our paper extends the literature on the valuation of VC-backed firms. Previous research has analyzed the effect of various determinants on the valuation of vC-backed firms, including firm characteristics (Hand, 2005; Armstrong et al., 2006), firm founder characteristics (Hsu, 2007), market conditions (Gompers and Lerner, 2000), venture capital characteristics (Cumming and Dai, 2011; Collewaert and Manigart, 2016), the role of bargaining power (Kirilenko, 2001; Fairchild, 2004; Heughebaert and Manigart, 2012), trademarks (Block et al., 2014) and corporate venture capital type (Rohm et al., 2018). However, there is little insight into the effect of investor attention on the valuation of VC-backed firms. We fll in this gap. Our paper also contributes to emerging literature on investor attention. Investor attention can impact stock prices and behavior of publicly traded securities in the aftermarket through trading volume (Gervais et al., 2001; Hou et al., 2009), media coverage and headlines (Palomino et al., 2009; Yuan, 2015; Chahine et al., 2015; Ahmad et al., 2016; Sun et al., 2020) and social media (Danbolt et al., 2015; Leitch and Sherif, 2017; Ga0 et al., 2019; Feng and Johansson, 2019). In addition, investor attention also influences IPO valuation and initial returns in the premarket Derrien, 2005; Alimov and Mikelson, 2012; Clarke et al., 2016). However, our paper, as far as we know, is the first to present empirical evidence about how investor attention affects the pricing in the venture capital market.  

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 discusses institutional environment and literature review. Section 3 describes data construction and provides summary statistics. In Section 4, we report the baseline results and examine the long-run performance of firm valuations and the performance of VC investments. Section 5 examines robustness tests, including sample selection, endogeneity and alternative measures of AsVI. Section 6 investigates the effect of syndication and involvement of experienced VCs on firm valuations. Section 7 concludes the paper.  

## 2. Institutional environment and literature review  

### 2.1.Institutional environment  

China, as one of the largest emerging economies, has many unique characteristics including venture capital industry and listing regulations. This section first discusses some different factors related to the VC market in China. First, venture capital in China is crucially different from that in advanced economies, including the selection of firms to fund (Baum and Silverman, 2004), monitoring processes and exit strategies (Bruton and Ahlstrom, 2003). For instance, in the selection process, venture capitalists in advanced economies mainly rely on financial and accounting information to evaluate the proposed ventures (Mcgrath, 1997) while in emerging economies they tend to fund firms that are located nearby in order to understand the local regulations (Bruton and Ahlstrom, 2003), which may cause the different behavior of venture capitalists in assessing and pricing the ventures.  

Second, venture capitalists in China are not as mature as their counterparts in developed markets, especially in the U.S., given that the history of venture capital in China traces back only to the 1990s. Wang and Wang (2011) also document that foreign VCs significantly outperform domestic VCs (i.e., the Chinese VC firms) in fundraising, investment amount, the number of investment deals and portfolio company performance. The short history and the underperformance of Chinese VC firms make them less mature and more easily influenced by sentiment investors who are prone to set the prices above or below the fundamental value of an asset (Black, 1986; Ljungqvist et al., 2006).  

Third, China’ VC industry experiences rapid expansion and has attracted much interest from global investors. The amount of newly raised funds increased from US\$ 675 million in 1999 to US\$ 104,262 million in 2015 and the number of funds increased from 87 in 1999 to 7665 in 2015 (Que and Zhang, 2020). Moreover, China is one of the most favored investment destinations of VCs in the world. The amount of investment made by foreign venture capital accounted for over $65\%$ of the total investment in China between 2001 and 2008 (Guo and Jiang, 2013). Therefore, our study benefits not only venture capital investors in China but also global venture capital investors.  

In addition, in contrast to a mature market in which conducting an IPO is a decision made by the issuer (Kao et al., 2009), firms in China need to satisfy higher standards regarding financial indicators and obtain approvals from the CsRC in order to go public (Chen et al., 2016). Firms going public on different stock markets require different financial standards. In fact, China's A-share market consists of four main parts, including the Main Board Market, Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Board Market, Growth Enterprise Market and SSE STAR Market.? Firms going public on the Main Board Market and the Small and Medium-sized Enterprise Board Market need to meet the same financial standards. The net profits of firms should be all positive in the three consecutive years prior to  

IPO and accumulatively more than 30 million RMB. Firms going public on the Growth Enterprise Market need to be profitable in the two consecutive years prior to IPO and the accumulated net profits in the two years prior to IPO are not less than 10 million RMB. There are no strict financial requirements for firms going public on the SSE STAR Market. Therefore, companies in China must be profitable in order to go public successfully on China's A-share market except SSE STAR Market.3  

### 2.2. Literature review and hypothesis  

Valuing start-ups, especially at early stages, is challenging given the lack of historical data, considerable uncertainty and informational asymmetry (Nahata, 2008; Festel et al., 2013). Classical theory argues that valuation for start-ups, to a large extent, is determined through the negotiation between venture capitalists and entrepreneurs (Hsu, 2007; Cumming and Dai, 2011; Heughebaert and Manigart, 2012). Therefore, previous literature focuses mainly on the determinants of negotiation power on both sides, including venture quality (Armstrong et al., 2006; Hsu, 2007; Gompers et al., 2010) and VC characteristics (Hsu, 2004; Cumming and Dai, 2011). However, retail investor attention, as a precursor of retail demand for shares in the aftermarket (Barber and Odean, 2008), may contain valuable clues about latent investor demand and reflect the intrinsic quality of start-ups (Colaco et al., 2017), which influences expectations of venture capitalists and in turn venture valuations. Consequently, incorporating retail attention could lead to more appropriate valuations for venture capitalists.  

Investor attention influences the expectations of venture capitalists in two strands. First, in the premarket, an increase in retail investors or the mere presence of retail investors could lead to higher initial IPO valuation (Colaco et al., 2017), higher IPO offer prices (Cornelli et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2007) or larger first-day returns for an IPO (Derrien, 2005; Bajo and Raimondo, 2017). Therefore, issuers, underwriters and institutional investors would benefit from a large IPO price run-up when they sell IPO shares to sentiment investors (Ljungqvist et al., 2006; Colaco et al., 2017), which even leads them to induce sentiment investors into the market for an IPO (Cook et al., 2006). Venture capitalists, as participants in the premarket, also benefit from these sentiment investors and thus expect to gain high exit proceeds given the high IPO valuation.  

In addition, as pointed out by Barber and Odean (2008), retail attention is a precursor of retail demand for shares in the aftermarket. An increase in retail demand causes temporary positive price pressure and drives up stock prices, which would bring VCs high returns when they sell shares in the aftermarket. As a consequence, when retail investors increasingly pay attention to an industry, VCs will anticipate strong latent investor demand and high exit returns in the aftermarket, resulting in a willingness to offer higher valuations to all firms in this industry (i.e., the “attention hypothesis").  

However, an increase in firm valuations is also likely explained by fundamental information reflected from favorable news about the industries. There are three aspects to illustrate our concerns. First, an industry is during the period of rapid growth or booms, such as personal computer hardware manufactures in the 1980s and Internet retailers and telecommunications concerns in the late 1990s (Gompers et al., 2008; Lu et al., 2013). Second, the government issues positive policies to support high-tech industries, such as software industry or 5G (Grilli and Murtinu, 2014). Third, there are major technological discoveries in an industry, such as development of genetic engineering (Lerner, 2002). Positive news about an industry's prospects will increase interest in online searches related to the industry and improve the expectations of all firms in the industry, which makes venture capitalists willing to pay higher prices to startups in this industry (i.e., the “fundamental hypothesis").  

The attention hypothesis and fundamental hypothesis may be distinguished from three aspects. First, according to Barber and Odean (2008) and Da et al. (2011), over-enthusiasm of retail investors could drive up firm valuations temporarily, and the firms eventually revert to their fundamental value when investor attention dissipates, causing a long-run underperformance (Ritter and Welch, 2002; Ljungqvist et al., 2006). Therefore, if the price increase is driven by investor attention, firm valuations will increase temporarily and eventually revert in the long run. However, if the price increase is due to fundamental information, no long-run reversal is expected. As a result, the long-run performance provides us with a natural venue to examine whether an increase in firm valuations is driven by investor attention or fundamental information.  

Second, Gompers and Lerner (2000) argue that if high valuations are rational responses to fundamental information about the changing prospects, investments should be more successful and exhibit better performance. In other words, if the investments do not exhibit better performance, high valuations should be driven by investor attention rather than fundamental information. Consistent with Hochberg et al. (2007), the performance of VC investments is measured by the performance of successful exits (Brander et al.,. 2002; Sorensen, 2007) and exit return multiples of venture capital. Our tests therefore focus on whether there are high probability of successful exits and high exit return multiples.  

Third, Heughebaert and Manigart (2012) argue that syndication can alleviate the information asymmetry and improve the quality of the decision (Wright and Lockett, 2003; Cumming and Walz, 2010). It is also well-documented that more experienced managers have a higher degree of skill and sophistication with respect to analyzing financial statements and forecasting firm valuations (Bushee, 1998; Cumming and Walz, 2010; Butler and Goktan, 2013). Therefore, if an increase in firm valuations is driven by investor attention, this overvaluation could be reduced by these adjustments of investment strategies that make VCs less vulnerable to investor sentiment. However, if the price increase is due to fundamental information, firm valuations could not be reduced by syndication or experience which on the contrary could help VCs pay more reasonable prices close to fundamental value. Consequently, we distinguish the attention hypothesis and fundamental hypothesis by exploring whether syndication and involvement of experienced VCs reduce the  

effect of investor attention on firm valuations  

## 3. Data and descriptive statistics  

### 3.1. Data and sample construction  

Information about venture investments, including valuation data, comes from the CVSource database. CVSource is a professional database which provides information about both venture capital firms and their portfolio companies in the Chinese private equity market. Our observations have venture names, financing dates, stages, rounds, venture industry, post-money valuation, the amount invested in each round, ownership held by VC and establishment date of venture capital. Firms that have received financing from individual investors are excluded from our sample. Following Cumming and Dai (2011), We define the firm valuations, Ln(pre-money valuation),4 as the natural logarithm of the difference between post-money valuation and the amount of capital invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars.  

The data used to measure investor attention comes from Baidu Index (http:/index.baidu.com). Although prior studies (Da et al., 2011; Gao et al., 2019) mainly use Google SVI to measure investor attention, we choose Baidu SVI instead of Google SVI because Baidu has the largest market share of internet search engines in mainland China (Ying et al., 2015). According to an analysis on the Chinese search engine market in 2018, Baidu makes up $70.3\%$ of the market share for mainland China. Consequently, the search volume from Baidu is representative of the internet search behavior of the general population of mainland China. Since Baidu Index provides the daily SVI of search terms dating back to June 2006, our sample covers the period from June 2006 to December 2017. We employ a web crawling program to obtain the daily SVI of each industry and construct our measure of AsVI.  

Our next concern is to identify the industries of VC-backed firms. We choose Shenwan Industry Classification to measure venture industry in our paper. Shenwan is a well-known securities company in China and takes into account the industry classification of both the government and industry management department when setting up the industries. In addition, Shenwan Industry Classification is well used in stock market in China and therefore is convenient to match public market industry index to VC-backed firms. According to Shenwan classification system, there are three levels of industry classifications and we use the third-level classification (six-digit code) to measure investor attention to an industry.  

However, the names of some industries could not be searched directly and generate a valid sVI in Baidu Index. In addition, some industries are not appropriate to be used directly as search terms, such as industries with too few firms or that are vaguely identified. Four steps are taken to overcome these problems. First, we try to substitute the industry by using a synonym for which Baidu Index can return a valid SVI. Second, for some industries that contain too few firms, we use the second-level industry (four-digit code) as a substitute. Third, although Shenwan has well classified firm industries, there are still some industries that are vaguely identified and cannot reflect firms’ main business accurately. In this case, we manually divide the industries into existing industries or new subindustries based on firms? main business. Fourth, for industries that could not be substituted by synonyms or firms that have valuation data but no industry data, we manually match each firm to the existing industries or to sub-industries based on its main business, and keep those firms that can be assigned to specific industries. In the end, there are left 5621 rounds (i.e., including $4305~\mathrm{firms}$ of venture capital investments? with valuation data in 229 industries with valid sVIs. We discuss our industry classifications in more detail in Appendix C.6  

### 3.2. Construction of ASVI  

In this part, we discuss the construction of investor attention to an industry. Using the daily SVI for each industry, we follow Chen et al. (2013) and Jiang et al. (2016) and first define abnormal investor attention (△sVI) for industry i on financing day t in Eq (1) as:  

$$
\Delta\mathrm{SVI}_{i,t}=\frac{S V I_{i,(t-30,t-1)}-S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)}}{S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)}}
$$  

where SVIis the daily search frequeny from Baidu Inexbased on the industry, $S V I_{i}$ $(t{-}30,t{-}1)$ is the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing day t for industry i, and $S V I_{i}$ $(t{-}60{,}t{-}31)$ is the SVI during the previous 30 days for industry i.  

In addition, we observe substantial differences in abnormal attention across industries. Consistent with Da et al. (2015) and Ga0 et al. (2019), we use the following method to construct an adjusted abnormal investor attention in our paper. First, to mitigate any concern about outliers, we winsorize △sVI at the $1\%$ level. Then, to eliminate differences across industries, we regress △sVI on industry dummies and keep the residuals. Finally, to address heteroscedasticity and make the industries comparable, we normalize these residuals by using their standard deviations. In the end, we obtain adjusted (winsorizing, eliminating industry bias, standardizing) abnormal investor attention, defined as AsVI, to measure investor attention to an industry.  

### 3.3. Descriptive statistics  

Table 1 reports summary statistics of the control variables for VC-backed firms between 2006 and 2017.7 The control variables in our paper consist of firm characteristics, venture capital characteristics and market conditions. First, we control for firm characteristics including the stage of ventures and the location of ventures following Gompers and Lerner (2000) and Cumming and Dai (2011). Early equals one for financing provided to ventures that have initial product, a rough business plan and an incomplete management team. The venture has usually been in business less than two years, but has not sold their product commercially. Development equals one for financing provided to ventures with product in testing or pilot production. The venture has not generated sale revenue, but starts to implement the market development plan. Expansion equals one for financing provided to ventures in need of growth and expansion capital. The venture may not break even or trade profitably. Capital is used to finance increased production capacity, for market or product development, to provide additional working capital. Profitable equals one if the venture has reached profitable operating level. The venture usually prepares to go public. $^8{\cal B}J$ equals one if the venture is located in Beijing and zero otherwise. SH equals one if the venture is located in Shanghai and zero otherwise. $G D$ equals one if the venture is located in Guangdong province and zero otherwise. $Z J$ equals one if the venture is located in Zhejiang province and zero otherwise. We choose BJ, SH, GD and $Z J$ as control variables because the number of investment rounds in these four regions is the largest, far larger than those located elsewhere. In addition, venture capital institutions are geographically concentrated in these four regions (Que and Zhang, 2020).  

Second, we control for the following measures of VC characteristics affecting firm valuations. Ln(Investment) is defined as the natural logarithm of the amount invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. Ownership is the ownership held by venture capital in the financing round. Ln(Number of investors) is the natural logarithm of the number of venture capital investors in the financing round (Heughebaert and Manigart, 2012). $G V C^{9}$ is defined as one if a venture capital firm is established, controlled and operated by the central government or local government and zero otherwise (Zhang and Mayes, 2018). $C V C^{10}$ is defined as one if a venture capital firm is a subsidiary of a corporation and zero otherwise. $F V C^{11}$ is defined as one if a venture capital firm's headquarter is located overseas or its capital is from abroad and zero otherwise (Que and Zhang, 2020). Syndication equals one if there is more than one VC investor in the same round and zero otherwise (Cumming and Walz, 2010; Guo and Jiang, 2013; Hsu et al., 2020). Experience is the natural logarithm of one plus the number of years from the establishment date of venture capital that makes the largest total investment in the financing round to the financing round (Gompers, 1996; Nahata, 2008; Cumming and Walz, 2010).  

Third, market conditions include two measures, an overall market index and an industry index. The overall market index is Ln(IPOs last year) which is defined as the natural logarithm of the number of IPOs in the previous year (Cumming and Dai, 2011). The industry index is industry public market index which is defined as the simple average of monthly returns of publicly traded firms in the same industry as the venture at the end of the month prior to the financing (Gompers and Lerner, 2ooo). Appendix E defines all variables used in this paper.

2014). When the stock market entered into a bear market in 2016, AsVI drops from 1.395 in 2015 to $-0.12$ in 2016 and pre-money valuation plunges from 244.058 in 2015 to 153.281 in 2016 (in thousands of US dollars). Similar phenomena exist in the period from the bull market in 2007 to the bear market in 2008.12 This evidence suggests that investor attention to industries is positively related to firm valuations.  

Table 3 provides descriptive statistics of pre-money valuation based on firm characteristics and round size. Most of our findings are consistent with Gompers and Lerner (2000) and Cumming and Dai (2011). For instance, pre-money valuation increases with the size of financing round. The mean pre-money valuation in the largest quartile of financing rounds is 468.888, compared with 29.439 in the smallest quartile of financing rounds (in thousands of Us dollars). In addition, pre-money valuation increases with development stage; Early is the lowest and Profitable is the highest. Firms located in Beijing (BJ), Shanghai (SH), Guangdong province $(G D)$ and Zhejiang province (ZJ) have higher valuations than those located elsewhere.  

## 4. Empirical results  

In this section, we examine the influence of investor attention on firm valuations in the venture capital market. Section 4.1 examines how investor attention to industries influences firm valuations. In Section 4.2, we explore whether firm valuations are induced by investor attention or fundamental information.

### 4.1. Baseline regression  

We first assess the effect of investor attention to industries on the valuation of VC-backed firms. Following previous studies (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Cumming and Dai, 2011), we adopt a hedonic regression approach to examine the effect. The dependent variable is pre-money valuation and the independent variables include firm characteristics, venture capital characteristics and market environment. We control for year and industry as fixed effects in our model. The following model in Eq. (2) is used to examine the effect of investor attention to industries on firm valuations.  

$$
V a l u a t i o n_{k,l}=\alpha_{0}+\alpha_{1}A S V_{k,l}+F i r m~c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s_{k,l}+V C~c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s_{k,l}+M a r k e t~c o n d i t i o n s_{k,l}+\epsilon_{k,l}
$$  

where Valuationk, $t$ is the pre-money valuation of firm $k$ on financing day t, $A S V I_{k}$ $t$ is investor attention to the industry of $\mathrm{firm}k$ on financing day t, Firm characteristics consist of stage information (Early, Development and Expansion) and location information (BJ, SH, GD and ZJ), VC characteristics include the amount invested by VC, the ownership held by VC, the number of VC investors, GVC, CVC, FVC and VC experience, Market conditions include the number of IPOs in the previous year and the industry public market index at the end of the month prior to the financing. Detailed definitions for the control variables are described in Section 3.3.  

Table 4 reports the relationship between investor attention to industries and firm valuations. The dependent variable is defined as the natural logarithm of the difference between post-money valuation and the amount of capital invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. Table 4 Column (1) examines the relationship for the full sample. The results show that the coefficient of AsVI is significant and positive, suggesting that firms in an industry with higher investor attention experience higher premoney valuation. Specifically, one standard deviation increase in investor attention increases the valuation of the firm by $1.13\%$ .In addition, investment size is significantly and positively related to pre-money valuation. The good public market conditions can increase firm valuations in the venture capital industry. High ownership held by VCs has significant and negative effect on pre-money valuation, which is probably due to the high bargaining power from VCs. More VC members and more experienced VCs offer lower valuations. Location and different VC types (GVC, CVC and FVC) are not significantly associated with firm valuations.  

We also divide the full sample into two groups based on financing rounds because firm valuations may be affected by differences between the first and later round investors. Lerner (1994b) argues that established VC groups tend to syndicate second and later financing rounds with less established investors. These changing syndication patterns may influence firm valuations. In addition, Gompers and Lerner (2000) and Hand (2005) document that later rounds are related to a substantial premium. From the perspective of investor attention, VCs in the first rounds are more easily affected by investor sentiment and set the price that deviates from fundamental value due to lack of historical data. To examine the difference, we segment our sample into the first round groups in Column (2) and the later round groups (i.e., all non-first financing rounds) in Column (3). We find that results for both the first round groups and later round groups are consistent with results for the full sample, supporting our notion that AsVI is positively associated with the valuation of VC-backed firms.  

### 4.2.Investor attention or fundamental information?  

Although we have shown that investor attention to industries is positively associated with firm valuations in the above analysis, fundamental information reflected by the positive news could also account for it. Favorable news about an industry's prospects will lead to an increase in search frequency (SVI) related to the industry, which could improve the expectations for all firms in an industry and in turn cause an increase of valuations for those firms. In this section, we will provide two pieces of evidence that is inconsistent with such information-based fundamental hypothesis.  

The first venue is the prediction for long-run performance. According to Da et al. (2011), if an initial price increase is driven by investor attention, firms eventually come back to their fundamental value when attention dissipates, causing the valuation to increase temporarily and then revert in the long run (Ritter and Welch, 2002; Ljungqvist et al., 2006). However, if the initial price increase is caused by positive fundamental information, no long-run reversal is expected. Consistent with these ideas, we wish to examine whether there is a long-run reversal in valuation for VC-backed firms. However, given that valuation data in the venture capital industry typically has gaps of one to two years between financing rounds (Gompers and Lerner, 20oo), we cannot investigate long-run performance as it occurs in the aftermarket. Instead, we examine whether there is a reversal in the subsequent financing rounds.  

Table 5 reports the results for reversals in the subsequent financing rounds. Specifically, the main independent variable of interest, ASVI, is investor attention to industries in the current round and the dependent variable is pre-money valuation in the subsequent round with a gap of one year, i.e., more than three months and less than sixteen months. The reason why we choose a gap of one year is that the mean gap between refinancings is 12.72 months in our sample. We choose a minimum gap of more than three months as it is likely that the influence of investor attention on firm valuations in the current and subsequent round would overlap if the gap was any smaller. We choose “less than sixteen months"’ as the maximum gap since investor attention would likely lose influences on firm valuations if the gap was any longer. Concerning that the results could be time-dependent, we control a time-interval related variable, △time, defined as the number of months from the current financing round to the next financing round. In addition, we also control the ASVI in the next financing round, labelled as ASVI Next, in our regression.  

The results show that the coefficient of AsVI is significant and negative, demonstrating that an increase in AsVI in the current round predicts a reversal of firm valuations in the subsequent round. Specifically, one standard deviation increase in investor attention in the current round predicts a decline in firm valuations in the subsequent round of $10.40\%$ In addition, we examine the results for the first round investments and find a consistent result. Our findings, to some extent, suggest that price increase is an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium.  

The second distinguishing feature between the attention-induced price increase and the information-based alternative is the performance of VC investments. Gompers and Lerner (2000) document that if fundamental information about the changing prospects results in high valuations, investments should be more successful and exhibit better performance. Therefore, if VC investments do not exhibit better performance, we can conclude that it is investor attention rather than fundamental information that pushes firm valuations up. Next, we investigate whether there is better performance of VC investments.  

Consistent with Hochberg et al. (2007), the performance of VC investments is measured by the performance of both the VC and the VC's portfolio companies. At the portfolio company level, we examine whether the companies achieve a successful exit, following

Brander et al. (2002), Sorensen (2007) and Humphery-Jenner and Suchard (2013) in viewing a successful exit as a signal of the investment's success. At the VC level, in the absence of available data on IRR (internal rates of returns), we instead use limited data on exit return multiples of venture capital disclosed by CVSource database to examine VC performance.  

We first analyze the effect of AsVI on the probability of successful exits of VC's portfolio companies. The venture is defined to have a successful exit if it exits via an IPO or a sale to another company (trade sell), or if it receives new financing with a gap of more than one year between the current and new financing rounds. Besides the typically successful forms of exit (via an IPO or trade sale), we view receiving new financing as a successful form considering that Hochberg et al. (2007) define survival to another funding round as an interim signal of success. We choose a gap of more than one year between refinancings for the following two reasons. First, the mean gap between refinancings is 12.72 months in our sample. Second, VC is a long-term strategic investor and provides value-adding services for the ventures. Therefore, we view the persistently performance well for a period of time after the investment to be sucessful.  

In addition, to alleviate the bias that some firms could not be defined to have a successful exit only because they have no enough time to mature to the point of being taken public (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Cumming and Dai, 2011), our sample only examines the ultimate success of venture investments before 2013. Table 6 Column (1)-(4) report the results of a probit regression of the probability of successful exits via only IPO, only trade sale, IPO and trade sale, and receiving new financing on AsVI, respectively. The results show that firms in industries with higher investor attention exhibit a lower probability of successful exits, that is, worse performance of VC investments, supporting for the attention hypothesis.  

To further examine how AsVI and valuation jointly influence the ultimate performance of VCs' portfolio companies, we divide our sample into two parts based on the median of pre-money valuation and report the results in in Table 6 Column (5)-(6). We find that the effect of AsVI on the probability of successful exits via an IPO is significant only for firms with relatively high pre-money valuation. Together with our findings in Table 4, this result suggests that the worse performance of VC investments appears to be driven entirely by the part of high investor attention. The analysis provides stronger evidence that firm valuations are induced by investor attention rather than fundamental information.  

We next examine a sample of exit return multiples disclosed by the CVSource database. This data is available for 748 of the 5621 financing rounds in our sample. While this sample is small and not necessarily representative, it provides us with an opportunity to partially examine the relationship between AsVI and exit return multiples. Table 7 reports the results of the effect of AsVI on exit return multiples. We find that the coefficient of AsVI is insignificant but negative, suggesting that firms in an industry with higher investor attention experience lower exit return multiples to some extent. When dividing our sample into two parts based on the median of pre-money valuation, we find significant and negative relationship between AsVI and exit return multiples only among the group with relatively high pre-money valuation. In line with the evidence in Table 6, our findings demonstrate that AsVI is negatively associated with the performance of VC investments, especially for financing rounds with high pre-money valuation. This evidence supports for the attention hypothesis.  

To summarize, we find that increases in AsVI predicts increases in firm valuations. Moreover, the increase in firm valuations is an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium due to the evidence of a long-run reversal of firm valuations and worse performance of VC investments. Our findings provide support for the attention-induced hypothesis.  

## 5. Robustness tests  

This section undertakes a variety of diagnostic analyses. In Section 5.1, we use a Heckman approach to address sample selection bias. Section 5.2 addresses the endogeneity problem by introducing instrumental variables. In Section 5.3, we repeat the baseline analysis using alternativemeasures of AsVI.  

### 5.1.A Heckman approach to deal with sample selection bias  

The valuation data comes from CVSource database, which collects data on firms in China that have received venture capital financing. However, a substantial portion of financing rounds in the CVSource database do not disclose valuation data, which may result in systemic biases between rounds with valuation data and those without valuation data (Gompers and Lerner, 2000; Cumming and Dai, 2011). To address this concern, we employ the Heckman sample selection approach to make sure that the omissions of valuation data do not cause selection biases in our analysis.  

The Heckman procedure suggests a correction for potential selection biases in two steps (Heckman, 1979). A first regression, the selection equation, measures the probability that there will be valuation data. Specifically, a first stage probit regression is based on the dependent variable which equals one if valuation data for a financing round is disclosed and zero otherwise. The independent variables for the first stage regression are firm characteristics including BJ, SH, GD, ZJ, Early, Development and Expansion, VC characteristics including the amount invested by venture capital, the number of investors, GVC, CVC, FVC and Experience, and market conditions

Table 8 reports the results of the second stage of the Heckman procedure. The second step presents a regression analysis of premoney valuation on AsVI and other control variables including the inverse Mills ratio. As shown in Table 8, the significant inverse Mills ratio indicates that selection bias is present due to the omission of valuation data. However, after controlling for the selection effect, firms in industries with higher investor attention still have higher valuations. Specifically, one standard deviation increase in investor attention predicts an increase in firm valuations of $0.79\%$ . The significant coefficient suggests that our results are robust with this alternative approach. In addition, when we examine the first round investments, we find consistent conclusions with those for the full sample, demonstrating that our results are not affected by the sample selection.  

### 5.2. An instrumental variable approach to address endogeneity problem  

In this study, although we show that the price increase is not induced by fundamental information, we may have omitted important explanatory variables that could contribute to firm valuations. Judge et al. (1985) document that omitted variable bias could inflate the coeficients of correlated independent variables. This omission may cause us to falsely impute significance to the measure of investor attention to industries. We address this problem with an instrumental variable approach. The instrumental variable should be correlated with investor attention to industries, but unrelated to the residuals in our model. We employ two methods to construct the instrumentalvariables.  

We first adopt the median AsVI of other peer industries that share the same four-digit CVSource industry (or six-digit industry when we need to divide an industry into to more specific sub-industries) with the specific venture as the instrumental variable,13 defined as ASVI_IV. We believe this is a reasonable choice of an instrumental variable for two reasons. First, it is clear that AsVI and AsVI_IV are correlated. Industries used to measure AsVI and AsVIIV belong to the same four-digit industry and thus are naturally related, such as fodder and livestock breeding, building construction and real estate development. As a consequence, when individual investors pay attention to an industry, they are also interested in another closely related industries, causing a simultaneous increase in SVI for both of them. Second, once the median AsVI is determined, it should be matched to a specific industry. Therefore, it is unlikely that the AsVI of a specific industry can directly influence the valuation of firms in another industry.  

In addition, we construct an alternative instrumental variable using the mean of advertising expenditure of all listed firms in the same industry with the specific venture. There are two reasons to choose advertising expenditure as an instrumental variable of investor attention. First, as advertising increases firms’ exposure to consumers and investors, the increased visibility may draw the attention of potential investors (Barber and Odean, 2008; Ding et al., 2017). Grullon et al. (2004) also point out that firms with high advertising expenditure are more visible to investors and attract a larger number of both individual and institutional investors. Therefore, high advertising expenditure is related to high investor attention. Second, because the advertising expenditure of a large majority of private firms is unavailable, we use advertising expenditure of all public firms in China's A-share market to construct our instrumental variable. Obviously, the mean of advertising expenditure for all public firms in an industry is not directly associated with a specific private firm valuation.  

Consistent with industry classification in our sample, we choose the third-level Shenwan classification (six-digit code) for all public firms. To match with the industries in our sample, we also manually divide the vaguely identified industries of public firms into subindustries or use the second-level industries to substitute industries with too few firms. The information of advertising expenditure comes from the “Notes to financial statements" in the CSMAR database.14 \*Notes to financial statements"15 records annual accounting items from 2010 to 2019 for all IPO firms in China in detail. Unlike balance sheet, there are no standard items for each firm and thus we need to extract the items related to advertising expenditure. Specifically, we choose the items that contain “advertising", “promotion", "publicity” and “exhibition" and sum their expenses as total advertising expenditure. In the end, we obtain annual advertising expenditure for each listed firm in China.  

An ideal instrumental variable should be measured using the mean of advertising expenditure in the corresponding period with AsVI, i.e.,from financing day $-60$ to $^{-1}$ . However, CSMAR database only collects annual accounting information. Therefore, we define the instrumental variable, AsVI IV_Adv, as the mean of advertising expenditure of all listed firms in the same industry with the specific venture at the end of the year prior to the financing. We use AsVI IV_Adv as an alternative instrument to address endogeneity

Table 9 repeats the OLS analysis from Table 4 and reports the results for the first and second stages of the instrumental variable approach. Panel A reports the result using the instrumental variable ASVIIV. The first stage regression is presented in Column (1). We find that the coefficient of ASVI IV is significant at the $1\%$ level, showing that ASVI IV is an appropriate instrument for investor attention to industries. The predicted values for AsVI are obtained from the first stage regression and are incorporated into the second stage regressions in Column (2). In the second stage, we find that the impact of AsVI on pre-money valuation is statistically significant and positive. Panel B reports the result using the alternative instrumental variable AsVI_IV_Adv. The first stage regression is presented in Column (3) and the second stage regresson is presented in Column (4). The result in Panel B is consistent with that in Panel A, supporting our notion that firms in industries with higher investor attention are associated with higher valuations.  

### 5.3. Alternative measures of investor attention to industries  

The AsVI used above is based on the change in SVI between the 30 days prior to the financing and the previous 30 days, which captures the deviation of investor attention from the “normal' part. However, the time window used to calculate the normal level is quite arbitrary. Da et al. (2011) use the median of Google SVI during the previous eight weeks as the benchmark level. Gao et al. (2019) document that the weekly change in Google SVI could well capture investor attention. Barber and Odean (2008) employ 252 trading days over the previous one year to measure “"normal' trading volume. Therefore, we consider alternative measures of AsVI to examine ourresults.  

In Panel A of Table 10, we define △SVI_60d as  

$$
\Delta\mathrm{SVI}_{-}60\mathrm{d}_{i,t}=\frac{S V I_{i,(t-30,t-1)}-m e d\big(S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)},S V I_{i,(t-90,t-61)}\big)}{m e d\big(S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)},S V I_{i,(t-90,t-61)}\big)}
$$  

where SVI is the daily search frequency from Baidu Index based on the industry, $S V I_{i}$ ， $(t{-}30,t{-}1)$ is the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing day $t,$ and $M e d(S V I_{i},$ (t-60,t-31), $S V I_{i,}$ (t-90,t-61) is the median SVI during the previous two months, i.e. from day $^{-90}$ to $^{-31}$ We winsorize the outliers, eliminate industry bias and standardize the △sVI_60d in Eq. (3), and finally obtain a measure of AsVI with a 60-day window, defined as AsVI_60d.  

Similarly, In Panel B of Table 10, we define △SVI_90d with a 90-day window as  

$$
\Delta\mathrm{SVL}.90\mathrm{d}_{i,t}=\frac{S V I_{i,(t-30,t-1)}-m e d\big(S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)},S V I_{i,(t-90,t-61)},S V I_{i,(t-120,t-91)}\big)}{m e d\big(S V I_{i,(t-60,t-31)},S V I_{i,(t-90,t-61)},S V I_{i,(t-120,t-91)}\big)}
$$  

where SVI is the daily search frequency from Baidu Index based on the industry, $S V I_{i}$ $(t{-}30,t{-}1)$ is the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing day t for industry $i,$ and $M e d(S V I_{i},$ $_{(t-60,t-31),S V I_{i}}$ $_{(t-90,t-61)},S V I_{i}$ $(t{-}120,t{-}91)$ is the median SVI during the previous three months, i.e. from day $^{-120}$ to $^{-31}$ . Thus, we also obtain a measure of AsVI with a 90-day window, defined as AsVI_90d, after winsorizing the outlier, eliminating industry bias and standardizing the △sVI_9od in Eq. (4).  

Table 10 reports the results of these alternative measures. We find that the coefficient estimates of AsVI for both the 60-day window and 90-day window are significant and positive, suggesting that firms in industries with higher investor attention experience higher valuations even when investor attention is measured using different time windows. For example, the first column of Table 10 shows that one standard deviation increase in investor attention predicts an increase in firm valuations of $0.34\%$ .Consistent with the results in the baseline model, we also show that investment size and market conditions have significantly positive influences on firm valuations. Ownership and the number of investors are negatively associated with firm valuations. Location has no significant relationship with firm valuations. The evidence suggests that our main results carry through with these alternative measures.  

To summarize, we deal with sample selection bias using a Heckman approach, address endogeneity problem using an IV approach, and repeat our baseline analysis using alternative measures of AsVI. After all these robust tests, our conclusion that an increase in AsVI predicts higher firm valuations continues to hold.  

## 6. Syndication, experienced VCs and overpricing  

The above analysis provides direct evidence for the attention hypothesis by examining the long-run performance of firm valuations and the performance of VC investments when investor attention dissipates. According to the attention theory, we can imply that if an increase in firm valuations is driven by investor attention, this overvaluation could be attenuated by some adjustments of investment strategies that make VCs less vulnerable to investor sentiment, such as syndication or involvement of experienced VCs. However, if the price increase is due to fundamental information, investment strategies could not reduce firm valuations, on the contrary, could help

VCs pay more reasonable prices that do not deviate from the fundamental value. Therefore, we investigate whether syndicated investments and involvement of experienced VCs reduce the effect of investor attention on firm valuations to provide further support for the attentionhypothesis.  

Heughebaert and Manigart (2012) argue that having more investors involved in the investment decision is expected to improve the quality of the decision and reduce the risk of ventures (Jin et al., 2020). It is also well-documented that syndication alleviates the information asymmetry (Wright and Lockett, 2003; Cumming and Dai, 2010) and reduces overpricing (Cumming and Walz, 2010). Therefore, we examine the relationship between syndication and firm valuations. Following Cumming and Walz (2010) and Guo and Jiang (2013), we define syndication as a dummy which equals one if there is more than one VC investor in the same round and zero otherwise. Table 11 reports the results of the effect of syndicated investments on firm valuations. In Column (1), we examine the interaction between AsVI and syndication and find that syndicated investments significantly attenuate the effect of AsVI on pre-money valuation.  

Further, Column (2) and Column (3) report results for the subsamples of standalone investments and syndicated investments, respectively. The results show that the significant and positive relationship between AsVI and firm valuations occurs only in standalone investments but disappears in syndicated investments. This evidence suggests that syndication indeed reduces the effect of ASVI on firm valuations, which is consistent with the attention-induced hypothesis.  

Cumming and Walz (2010) also argue that more experienced managers are better able to forecast valuations precisely because they have a higher degree of skill and sophistication with respect to analyzing financial statements and forecasting firm valuations (Bushee, 1998; Butler and Goktan, 2013). More importantly, experienced VC firms have fewer incentives to overvalue investments given that they have more reputational capital at stake (Cumming and Walz, 2010). Consistent with this idea, we consider whether the experience of venture capitalists attenuates the effect of investor attention on firm valuations for VC-backed firms. Table 12 reports the regression results of venture capitalists’ experience on firm valuations. Following Gompers (1996), Nahata (2008) and Cumming and Walz (2010), we define experience as the natural logarithm of one plus the number of years from the establishment of venture capital that makes the largest total investment in the financing round to the financing round. The results in Column (1) show that experience has a significantly negative effect on pre-money valuation. Furthermore, when we examine the interaction variable between experience and ASVI, we find that the coefficient is also negative and significant, demonstrating that venture capitalists? experience reduces the effect of ASVI on firm valuations. This evidence suggests that having more experience makes VCs less vulnerable to investor sentiment and alleviates the overpricing induced by investor attention, supporting for the attention hypothesis.  

To summarize, we find that both syndicated investments and involvement of experienced VCs can reduce the effect of investor attention on firm valuations, which is inconsistent with the fundamental hypothesis that information-based firm valuations cannot be attenuated by investment strategies. Overall, our evidence provides further support for the attention hypothesis.  

## 7. Conclusion  

This paper explores the relationship between investor attention to industries and firm valuations in the venture capital industry. Unlike previous analyses which focus on public markets, our paper, as far as we know, provides the first empirical study on how investor attention influences the asset pricing in the venture capital market.  

Using aggregate search frequency in Baidu, we construct a direct measure of investor attention to an industry (AsVI) and find several main results. First, VC-backed firms with higher AsVI during the 30 days prior to the financing exhibit higher valuations. This result is robust to a variety of diagnostics analyses, including sample selection bias, endogeneity problem and alternative measures of ASVI. Second, an increase in firm valuations is an attention-induced result rather than an information-based fundamental premium, which is supported by the evidence of a long-run reversal of firm valuations and worse performance of VC investments. Third, syndicated investments and involvement of experienced venture capitalists can attenuate the effect of investor attention on firm valuations, which further support the attention hypothesis.  

Our findings show that the prices of venture capital investments are not just determined by the quality of ventures, the charac teristics of venture capital, or market conditions, but also influenced by investor attention. There is a tradeoff between investo: attention and the valuation that ventures can get. High attention can push up firm prices, however, as a tradeoff, the performance o both successful exits and exit return multiples is worse.  

Our findings also suggest that the overpricing driven by investor attention can be attenuated through some adjustments of investment strategies. These strategies make venture capitalists less vulnerable to investor sentiment and reduce the overpricing, which facilitates future performance of VC funds and subsequently their ability to raise future funds.

This table reports the influence of alternative measures of investor attention to industries on firm valuations. Panel A and Panel B present the results of financing rounds with AsVI for the 60-day window and 90-day window, respectively. The dependent variable is the natural logarithm of the difference between post-money valuation and the amount of capital invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. ASV60d is measured by regressing △SVI_60d on industry dummies to control for industry differences, keeping the residuals, then normalizing these residuals by using their standard deviations (△sVI_60d is defined by calculating the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing minus the median SVI during the previous two months, i.e. from day -90 to $^{-31}$ , scaled by the median SVI during the previous two months). ASVI 90d is measured by regressing △SVI_90d on industry dummies to control for industry differences, keeping the residuals, then normalizing these residuals by using their standard deviations (△sVI90d is defined by calculating the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing minus the median SVI during the previous three months, i.e. from day -120 to $^{-31}$ , scaled by the median SVI during the previous three months). Early equals one for financing provided to ventures that have initial product, a rough business plan and an incomplete management team. The venture has usually been in business less than two years, but has not sold their product commercially. Development equals one for financing provided to ventures with product in testing or pilot production. The venture has not generated sale revenue, but starts to implement the market development plan. Expansion equals one for financing provided to ventures in need of growth and expansion capital. The venture may not break even or trade profitably. Capital is used to finance increased production capacity, for market or product development, to provide additional working capital. BJ equals one if the venture is located in Beijing and zero otherwise. SH equals one if the venture is located in Shanghai and zero otherwise. GD equals one if the venture is located in Guangdong province and zero otherwise. ZJ equals one if the venture is located in Zhejiang province and zero otherwise. Ln(Investment) is the natural logarithm of the amount invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. Ownership is the ownership held by venture capital in the financing round. Ln (Number of investors) is the natural logarithm of the number of venture capital investors in the financing round. GvC equals one if a venture capital firm is established, controlled and operated by the central government or local government and zero otherwise. CVC equals one if a venture capital firm is a subsidiary of a corporation and zero otherwise. FVC equals one if a venture capital firm's headquarter is located overseas or its capital is from abroad and zero otherwise. Experience is the natural logarithm of one plus the number of years from the establishment of venture capital that makes the largest total investment in the financing round to the financing round. Ln(IPOs last year) is the natural logarithm of the number of IPOs in the previous year. Industry public market index is defined as the simple average of monthly returns of publicly traded firms in the same industry as the venture at the end of the month prior to the financing. All the regressioos control for year and industry fixed effects. T-statistics are reported in parentheses. $\cdots\ast\ast$ , and \* indicate significance at $1\%$ $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, respectively.

This table reports the influence of investor attention to industries on firm valuations for the subsamples with more than two rounds and three rounds, respectively. Column (1) presents the results for firms with more than two rounds. Column (2) presents the results for firms with more than three rounds. The dependent variable is the natural logarithm of the difference between post-money valuation and the amount of capital invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. ASVI is measured by regressing △SVI on industry dummies to control for industry differences, keeping the residuals, then normalizing these residuals by using their standard deviations (△sVI is defined by calculating the SVI during the 30 days prior to the financing minus the SVI during the previous 30 days, scaled by the SVI during the previous 30 days). Early equals one for financing provided to ventures that have initial product, a rough business plan and an incomplete management team. The venture has usually been in business less than two years, but has not sold their product commercially. Development equals one for financing provided to ventures with product in testing or pilot production. The venture has not generated sale revenue, but starts to implement the market development plan. Expansion equals one for financing provided to ventures in need of growth and expansion capital. The venture may not break even or trade profitably. Capital is used to finance increased production capacity, for market or product development, to provide additional working capital. BJ equals one if the venture is located in Beijing and zero otherwise. SH equals one if the venture is located in Shanghai and zero otherwise. GD equals one if the venture is located in Guangdong province and zero otherwise. ZJ equals one if the venture is located in Zhejiang province and zero otherwise. Ln(Investment) is the natural logarithm of the amount invested in the financing round, expressed in thousands of US dollars. Ownership is the ownership held by venture capital in the financing round. Ln(Number of investors) is the natural logarithm of the number of venture capital investors in the financing round. GVC equals one if a venture capital firm is established, controlled and operated by the central government or local government and zero otherwise. CVC equals one if a venture capital firm is a subsidiary of a corporation and zero otherwise. FVC equals one if a venture capital firm's headquarter is located overseas or its capital is from abroad and zero otherwise. Experience is the natural logarithm of one plus the number of years from the establishment of venture capital that makes the largest total investment in the financing round to the financing round. Ln(IpOs last year) is the natural logarithm of the number of IPOs in the previous year. Industry public market index is defined as the simple average of monthly returns of publicly traded firms in the same industry as the venture at the end of the month prior to the financing. All the regressions control for year and industry fixed effects. T-statistics are reported in parentheses. $\ddot{\cdots}\ddot{\cdots},\stackrel{\ast\ast}{\cdots}$ and \* indicate significance at $1\%$ $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, respectively.  

### Appendix C. Constructing industry classification  

In our sample, we use the third-level industries of Shenwan industry classifications in CVSource database to measure investor attention to an industry. However, the names for some industries could not be searched directly and generate a valid SVI in Baidu Index. In addition, some industries are also not appropriate to be used directly as search terms, such as industries with too few firms or that are vaguely identified. In this section, we use four steps to address these problems. First, we try to substitute the industry by using a synonym for which Baidu Index can return a valid sVI and report the results in Table C1. Second, for some industries that contain too few firms, we use the second-level industry (four-digit code) as a substitute and report the results in Table C2.  

Third, although Shenwan has well classified firm industries, there are still some industries that are vaguely identified and cannot reflect firms’ main business accurately. In this case, we manually divide the industries into existing industries or new sub-industries based on firms' main business. There is a specific case. Internet information services, Software Development and Computer application are emerging high-tech industries and the main business of firms in these industries are heavily overlapping. Therefore, we view these three industries as a whole and divide it into existing or new sub-industries based on firms′ main business. Table C3 reports the results.  

Fourth, for industries that could not be substituted by synonyms or financing rounds that have valuation data but no industry da we manually match each firm to the existing industries or to specific sub-industries based on their main business, and keep those firms that can be assigned to specific industries. Table C4 reports the results.  

In our paper, we search the names of industries in Baidu Index using Chinese language. However, we also report each industry in English in order to make them more convenient to understand. Appendix C tabulates the names of industries in three forms: English, Chinese and Chinese phonetic alphabets.
