As proposed in Hypothesis 2, studies that do not control for industry effects deliver substantially stronger effect sizes for the VC-performance relationship $\stackrel{\prime}{\Lambda}=0.10\stackrel{\cdot}{\Lambda}$ ) than studies that control for industry selection effects $'\Gamma=0.03\$ 0.The meta-analytic regression supports the result that industry control measures decrease the effect size significantly. To be more precise, the positive overall effect vanishes when studies incorporate industry control measures as the effect size among studies that control for industry effects is not significant. Taken together, the finding indicates that VCs choose the more promising industries, but are not able to consistently increase the funded firms' performance across all performance dimensions within an industry.  

Turning to differences in the performance measures, the bivariate analyses and the meta-regression do support Hypotheses 3a and 3b. Whereas VC investments have a small, positive impact on growth $(\Gamma=0.07$ ) and stock market performance $(\Gamma=0.08\$ they do not influence the profitability of the funded firms $\mathrm{\Delta}\Gamma=-0.03\$ . In many cases, VC investments are even associated with lower profitability (e.g., Jain et al., 2008; Wong and Wong, 2008). Although the confidence intervals of the sub-groups' "profitability-based studies" and “growth-oriented studies" slightly overlap, the other results (z value and increase in variance attributable to sampling error) indicate that the type of performance has a moderating influence on the strengths of the VC investment-performance relationship. The results of the meta-analytic regression further support this finding.  

Moreover,in additional post-hoc analyses we re-calculated the bivariate analyses of the different performance dimensions only with the studies that control for industry selection effects to determine whether additional intra-industry effects exist with respect to the different performance dimensions. We find that the effect of VC investment on growth remains significant $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.09$ O,while the effect on stock-market performance turns non-significant $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.03$ ), and the effect on profitability is negative $(\Gamma=-0.09$  

In addition, we tested the effects of firm age, IPO vs. non-IPO firms and uncertainty avoidance on the effect size. According to bivariate and multivariate analyses, firm age has the hypothesized curvilinear relationship with the VC-performance link. The influence on the VC investment-performance relationship, i.e. the relationship between VC and funded-firm performance is strongest in growth stage firms $\mathrm{\Delta}_{\mathrm{{I}}}=0.10$ ),ascomparedtonewventures $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.04$ and to established firms $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.04$ ).Themetaregression also supports Hypothesis 4 which proposes an inverted U-shaped effect as indicated by the negative coefficient for the squared term of firm age, which is significant.  

Although we do not find a significant difference between the effect sizes for post-IPO studies in comparison to pre-IPO studies, the multivariate regression analysis which simultaneously tests age effects and IPo effects indicates a significant difference between pre-IPO performance and post-IPO performance effects. Empirical studies investigating post-IPO effects report lower effect sizes than the pre-IPO studies lending support for hypothesis 5.  

Furthermore, the bivariate analysis indicates that firms in cultures with high uncertainty avoidance benefit significantly less from venturecapital $(\Gamma=0.00)\$ )than firms in cultures with low uncertainty avoidance $'\Gamma=0.08$ ). Yet, the coefficient for uncertainty avoidance is not significant when we control for additional moderators in the meta-regressions. Hence, we have to reject Hypothesis 6.  

Our control variables further indicate that the event of VC investment has a stronger impact on firm performance $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.08$ than continuous measures of VC investment $'\Gamma=0.01$ ). This finding is, however not supported by the meta-analytic regression. Furthermore, we do not find evidence of a publication bias overestimating the strength of the relationship. In fact, unpublished work shows higher effect sizes $\mathbf{\tilde{f}}=0.13$ )than published articles $\mathbf{\tilde{r}}{=}0.07\$ ). Although, the confidence intervals of the two respective sub-groups overlap slightly, the z value and the results of the meta-regressions demonstrate that publication has a significantly negative impact on the effect size.  

## 6. Discussion  

This study was motivated by three questions: whether, how, and especially under which circumstances VC investment benefits the funded firms. Prior research presented conflicting theoretical arguments as to how firm performance is affected by VC funding. Moreover, empirical findings were fragmented and inconclusive. Furthermore, the high variance in previous empirical findings pointed to the existence of contextual moderators. We built on prior theorizing about selection and post-investment value added effects and systematically structured our analysis according to the selection and value-added hypotheses (Brander et al., 2002; Dimov and Shepherd, 2005; Dimov et al, 2007; Lerner, 1994). Following an evidence-based research approach, we empirically synthesized research results based on 76 independent samples.  

Our results show that overall vC has a positive, yet, weak effect on the funded firm's performance. However, the overall performance effect disappears if researchers control for industry selection effects. Moreover, another part of the variance in empirical results can be attributed to contextual factors including the type of performance studied, the age of the firm, and whether it is a publicly-traded or private firm. Uncertainty avoidance, however, does not moderate the relationship between VC and funded firm performance. Our findings have important theoretical and practical implications and suggest various promising avenuesforfurtherresearch.  

### 6.1. Theoretical implications  

Theoretical debates regarding performance effects of vC investments center on how VC investments influence funded firm performance. A prominent stream of literature proposes that VCs have comparative advantages in comparison to other financial intermediaries when operating in environments of missing or asymmetrical information (Amit et al., 1998). Further research points to two important effects that could explain a positive performance impact of VC investments on funded firms: selection and post-investment value added effects (Brander et al., 2002; Dimov and Shepherd, 2005; Dimov et al., 2007; Lerner, 1994). The empirical evidence from this study suggests that selection or more specifically, inter-industry selection, seems to play an important role for positive performance effects of VC investments. The relationship between VC and funded firm performance is significantly stronger if researchers did not control for industry. This indicates that VCs are indeed able to identify and invest in the more promising industries. Readily available information about the structure, status, and dynamics of industries appears to enable VCs to select the more promising industries. Hence, when comparing VC funded vs. non-funded firm performance across industries a positive performance effect of VC funded firms' results.  

Strikingly, however, if researchers isolate the effect that VCs have on funded firms within an industry the comparative performance advantages of VC funded firms vanishes. This finding indicates that proposed advantages associated with VC investments might be partially offset by disadvantages. For example, in environments of missing or asymmetrical information, high risk and uncertainty, VCs might not be able to systematically identify the most promising firms within an industry (Amit et al., 1998). The inherent uncertainty of the entrepreneurial context might make predictions regarding who the winners within an industry dificult. Moreover, an adverse selection might cause that generally more subpar firms are willing to present themselves and take on VC investments. Taken together, our results raise doubts whether there is - on average - a positive intra-industry selectioneffect.  

Moreover, the post-investment performance benefits including the actual provision of financial resources, managerial support, and monitoring may be offset by disadvantages. For instance, the financial resources provided by the VCs may create a false sense of security and reduce the need to focus on close customer interaction and fast positive cash-flow generation. Also, dependencies and strategic rigidities that are attached to financial resources provided by the VCs might particularly confine the emergent organization's ability to flexibly change strategic directions. In addition, the funded firms might also need to absorb the substantial transaction-costs given the high degrees of risk and uncertainty which would lower their resulting performance. Further, the search for VC investments requires substantial managerial time and attention that, depending on the stage of the venture, might be spent more efficiently on alternative activities.  

The non-significant overall intra-industry effect is accompanied by strong indications of heterogeneity of the aggregated performance effects. Hence, we can assume that selection and post-investment effects unfold their benefits only on specific performance dimensions and under specific circumstances. Whereas the overall analysis combines all performance dimensions which leads overall to a non-significant relationship between VC investments and firm performance, the subsequent moderator analyses reveal a more differentiated picture. VC investments mainly lead to growth and higher valuations while profitability is unaffected. This finding supports our propositions that VCs strategically position their funded ventures to pursue growth paths while profitability increases are of a lesser concern or might not be achievable at the same time.  

An important contingent effect relates to the age of the funded firms. Our findings suggest there might be a trade-off between decreasing uncertainty and, thus, higher likelihood of positive selection and a decreasing return for financial resources and valueadded activities provided by VCs as ventures mature. Hence, we find indications for an optimal age or age range which we would term the “sweet-spot" of VC investments when these investments especially benefit the funded firms. More specifically, the inverted u-shaped relationship suggests that there is an optimal level of informational detail. If VCs invest very early, the lack of information might be excessive and lead to the VC's inability to successfully select. However, if they invest in very established firms, information is generally abundant and hence their specialized capabilities and relative advantage to operate in environments of risk and uncertainty lose value. Supporting this line of argument, we observe that the IPO event significantly alters the performance implications for the funded firms in addition to the age effects. Due to the disclosure requirements related to the IPO and as a public company, more information becomes available and information asymmetries decrease. The resulting decreasing uncertainty, in consequence, does limit VCs to provide unique value for their funded firms. Hence, our findings provide further support to scholars' theorizing that VCs have special capabilities to provide value in contexts of lacking and asymmetric information. It also suggests that the performance effects for the funded firms might depend on the availability of alternative financial resources. If access to substantial financial capital is available through other means such as the public markets, the value that VCs can provide likely diminishes.  

Overall, our findings suggest the need for a more contextual understanding of the VC investment-funded firm performance phenomenon in general and the selection and post investment benefits in particular especially taking into account the uncertainty of a venture. The variance of the effect sizes further cautions researchers to be sensitive to consider a comprehensive set of positive and negative outcomes of VC investments. Furthermore, researchers should take industry-selection effects into account when designing empirical studies and when drawing implications from their results. If scholars are interested and theorize about intra-industry effects of VC investment, but do not control for industry selection effects findings are likely biased. Moreover, research needs to focus on those dependent variables that are primary objectives of vC investments such as the evaluation of the funded firms and related growth metrics and take into consideration how the context impacts the availability of information and the resulting uncertainty.  

While our results caution to critically reflect on the far-spread assumption about the overall positive effects of VC investments, we also acknowledge that the value provided by the different VCs likely varies to a great extent (e.g., Fitza et al., 2009; Guler, 2007; Scherer et al., 2000). In consequence,first tier VCs might be more proficient in selecting the more promising ventures, providing more and more valuable resources, and bestowing the funded firms with more positive signaling effects than lower tier VCs.  

### 6.2. Managerial implications  

Taken together, findings presented in our study challenge the assumption that VCs systematically select the most promising ventures and add value to funded firms across different contexts. Much of the positive performance effects are due to industry selection effects. If an entrepreneur, however, has already selected an industry to operate in, these positive selection does not appear to substantiate. This suggests that entrepreneurs need to carefully consider the value a specific VC can provide for them. However, our findings also show that VC investments can be value-creating especially with regard to firm growth while their contribution to simultaneous profit improvements can be very limited or even negative. Hence, entrepreneurs should reflect on their personal priorities with regard to growth and profitability before they consider a VC investment.  

We further found that VC investments provide most value when firms are between 6 and 12 years old and when they are not yet publicly-traded. Thus, timing of the first investment and optimal duration of the investment seem to be important considerations in order to maximize the VC impact for the funded firm. At the same time, entrepreneurs should consider that in other stages VCs overall might impact the performance substantially less.  

### 6.3. Limitations  

Different limitations need to be acknowledged. First, we would like to highlight that to date no commonly accepted definition of VC exists. Prominent literature, however, argues that VCs are unique and differ from adjacent financial intermediary types such as business angels and LBO firms. In order to get a specific understanding of how VCs affect funded-firm performance, we aimed at excluding studies that included angel investments or LBO firms based on different study screening methods described in the Method section. However, a risk remains that authors of the primary studies included in this meta-analysis did not mention that these alternative financing forms are part of their samples.  

Second, a common shortcoming of meta-analyses is the publication bias (Rosenthal, 1979). While we identified a significant number of unpublished studies, overall access to unpublished studies is limited. However, we assume that a normative bias of editors to publish only significant findings or findings that highlight specific effects is limited, because the performance effects of VC financing have always been controversially discussed. This suggests that a normative publication bias is unlikely. The comparison of published vs. unpublished studies further reveals that the unpublished studies present stronger effect sizes than the published studies. This contradicts a publication bias which is generally considered an upward bias.  

Third, our results could suffer from a survival bias. VC-financed firms are generally pursuing strategies that promise greater returns, yet imply also greater chances of failure. Since the primary studies frequently do not account for differences in failure rates between VC-backed and non-VC-backed firms, the underlying studies may be biased, resulting in a potential survival bias of our aggregated findings. However, survival bias could have two opposing effects. On the one hand, firms that do not obtain VC funding might go bankrupt more often. On the other hand, the VC financed firms might aim for higher growth which could increase the risk of failure. Hence, it remains uncertain how a survival bias might affect the findings. This problem should be more frequently accounted for in the primary research. As researchers incorporate survival in their models of VC-performance effects, it allows future meta-analyses of survival effects.  

Fourth, our research highlights that industry selection effects impact the VC investment-performance relationship. In a similar manner, other selection effects might exist that determine which firm acquires VC funding. These non-observed VC selection effects or the endogeneity of the choice of entrepreneurs to opt for VC funding could also bias our findings (Hamilton and Nickerson, 2003). However, primary studies generally do not account for these more advanced modeling techniques. Such selfselection effects could be addressed if the primary studies would use random control experiments. Yet, given the VC context, such research design has not been used. Hence, in order to contextualize our findings, future primary research should aim at analyze both positive and negative self-selection effects of firms aiming for VC.  

### 6.4. Outlook  

This is the first meta-analysis analyzing the impact of VC-investment on the funded firms. The synthesis of previous literature illustrates frequent research frameworks and less scrutinized relationships. Hence, research gaps can be identified. In addition, our findings suggest opportunities for future research. We would like to highlight a few salient research opportunities. First, although this meta-analysis presented some indications regarding the value that VCs provide for their funded firm and under which circumstances these benefits unfold, further research is needed to improve our understanding of selection and post investment performance effects. The limited overall effect as well as the variance in the underlying effect sizes of the VC and funded firm performance relationship indicates that both positive and negative selection and post-investment factors are present. Further, these negative and positive effects may only unfold under specific circumstances.  

Hence, future research should aim at uncovering positive and negative effects for each of the two hypotheses (selection effects and post-investment performance effects), take the additional forms of a firms financing into account, and especially consider and report specific context factors such as stage of the VC investment and especially the quality of the VCs. In this regard, research frameworks that more thoroughly investigate the reputation of the different VCs, while simultaneously capturing the value of specific resources provided by VCs could advance current research. Although research on VCs reputation and their impact on funded firm performance exists (e.g., Brau et al., 2004; Campbell li and Frye, 2006; Nahata, 2008) the mechanisms behind these performance effects as well as their specific value remain unclear. For example, out of 10 studies in this analysis which look at different measures that could be somewhat related to the quality of the VCs, 7 find insignificant or mixed results. Moreover, we identified only four studies that specifically addressed the quality of the VC by having respondents rate the quality of the VC's activities. These studies obtain a non-significant average effect size of $\Gamma=0.016$ that is comparable to the overall effect when controlled for industry. Yet, we understand these initial findings as only suggestive and believe that more research needs to be directed as this aspect aiming for a more rigorous empirical measurement regarding the VC's quality and the resources they provide as well as an incorporation of longitudinal research designs to address causality concerns. A recent study by Krishnan et al. (2011) provides a step in this direction by separating selection and value-added effects and linking them to VCs reputation. Yet, this study looks at post-IPO performance effects and, thus, misses out on important stages of VC funding prior to an IPO.  

Moreover, the success of VC investments may depend on the expertise and the size of the VCs. Previous research has pointed out that the type of VC may influence strategy-making and the success of funded firms. For example, Makela and Maula (2005) argue that cross-border VC funding influences internationalization processes of funded firms. Furthermore, VCs affliated to banks or governments may have a different impact on the performance of funded firms than independent venture capitalists (e.g.,. Hamao et al., 2000; Tykvova and Walz, 2007). However, empirical research on these issues has been scarce. Another important perspective is that the individual partners of a VC might vary substantially in quality and resources they can provide. Hence, studies could focus more on the individual level to understand which individual factors of the VC partners affect the funded firm performance. In sum, more research on the characteristics of VCs and their moderating influence on the VC-performance link is needed, which in consequence would enable evidence-based researchers to address respective questions.  

Another important contingency that could not be addressed in the present study is the expertise of the funded firm's top management team. For instance, the ability of the entrepreneurs to collaborate with the VCs and to deploy capital effectively and efficiently appears to be another important yet under-researched contextual factor that impacts the VC investment performance relationship.  

Extant VC research predominantly focuses on IPO events. Out of the 76 independent samples integrated in this meta-analysis 59 focused on firms that had an IPO. This leads to a shortage of studies which scrutinize the impact of VCs on smaller and newer firms. Hence, more research about firms that are in the early stage of their life cycle and are of smaller size is warranted to complement the existing empirical work. This gap in research presents a special opportunity for entrepreneurship researchers. Research on IPO performance is dominated by finance scholars whose main interest is the explanation of stock-market performance differentials at and post-IPo. Because entrepreneurship as a field of research emphasizes the discovery and exploitation of opportunities (Shane and Venkataraman, 2001) and entrepreneurship scholars have an expertise in investigating dynamics of new ventures, entrepreneurship research is well-positioned to address the gap of research regarding early-stage VC investments. In this regard, we especially believe in the potential for entrepreneurship scholars to include non-financial aspects such as cognition of the VCs or entrepreneurs, strategy constructs, or team configuration variables in the analyses.  

In our call for further non-IPO or post IPO studies we also would like to address the value of replication studies. We are concerned that in entrepreneurship and management science scholars predominantly strive for novel research frameworks at the expense of repetition studies while in other disciplines such as medicine or education science replication and empirical synthesis are a common practice. We believe that future research would benefit if researchers would more regularly report findings regarding study elements that previous research addressed even if and especially if respective findings are non-significant.  

Further, we call for a more extensive description of the sampled VCs. Our provided overview of the studies underlines this shortcoming in extant research. Only one study distinguishes between funding stages when reporting bivariate statistics (Alemany and Marti, 2005). Two more studies explicitly include only start-ups (Engel and Keilbach, 2007; Stubner et al., 2007) while another study documents the focus on pre-IPO investments in growth stages (Wang et al., 2003). We believe that a more detailed description of the sampled funded firms and the characteristics of the VCs helps scholars contextualize the findings and can help in identifying more specific effects.  

Understanding the mechanisms via which VC investors add value to early-stage ventures still remains an under-researched, but important topic in the VC literature. Gaining further knowledge about these mechanisms and the contingencies under which they unfold their benefits would advance this stream of research. Because it is difficult to capture the performance effects of VC investments on early-stage ventures for instance due to the multi-dimensional nature of firm performance (Combs et al., 2005), researchers should use multiple measures including perceptual and objective indicators of firm performance and also consider that the importance of the performance dimensions for entrepreneurs and their investors might change as the firm develops and establishes itself in the marketplace.  

Overall, this study aimed at highlighting the need for a more contextual understanding of VC investment-performance. Specific variables relating to the funded firm, the funding VC and the funding context need to be taken into consideration when determining whether a VC investment is beneficial for the funded firm. While we see substantial progress VC research made in the last decades, we hope that our study serves as a point for reflection. We further hope that the suggested avenues for future research inspire scholars to identify specific mechanisms how more generally financial management can contribute to create value for entrepreneurial firms given the different investment contexts.

md_sapienzaVentureCapitalistGovernance19.reference_markdown:
# VENTURE CAPITALIST  

# GOVERNANCE AND  

# VALUE ADDED IN  

# FOUR COUNTRIES  

HARRY J. SAPIENZA University of South Carolina  

SOPHIE MANIGART University of Ghent, Belgium  

WIM VERMEIR University of Ghent, Belgium  

Therapidinternationalizationofmarketsforventurecapitalisexpandingthefundingalternativesavailabletoentrepreneurs.Forventure capitalfirms,thistrendspellsintensifiedcompetitioninmarketsalready at orpast saturation.At issueforboth entrepreneurs andventurecapital firms is how and when venture capitalists (VCs) can provide meaningful oversight and addvalueto theirportfoliocompaniesbeyond theprovision of capital. An important way VCs add value beyond the money they provide is through their close relationships with the managers of their portfolio companies. Whereas some VCs take a very hands-off approach to oversight, others become deeply involved in the development of their portfoliocompanies.  

Utilizing surveys of VCs in the United States and the three largest markets in Europe (the UnitedKingdom,theNetherlands,andFrance),weexaminedthedeterminantsofinteractionbetween VCs and CEOs, the roles VCs assume, and VCs' perceptions of how much value they add through these roles.We examined the strategic,interpersonal,and networking roles through which VCs are involved in their portfolio companies, and we analyzed how successful such efforts were. By so doing we were able to shed light on how and when VCs in four major markets expend their greatest effort to provide oversight andvalue-added assistance to their investment companies.  

Consistentwith prior empiricalwork,wefound thatVCs sawstrategicinvolvement as their most important role, i.e., providing financial and business advice and functioning as a sounding board.They rated their interpersonal roles(as mentor and confidant toCEOs) as next invalue.  

Finally,they rated their networking roles (i.e., as contacts to other firms and professionals) as third most important. These ratings were consistent across all four markets. VCs in the United States and theUnitedKingdom werethemost involved in theirventures,and they added the mostvalue. VCs in France were the least involved and added the least value; VCs in France appeared to be least like others in terms of what factors drove their efforts. Our theoretical models explained a greater proportion of variance in governance and value added in the United States than elsewhere. Clear patterns of behavior emerged that reflect the manner in which different markets operate. Among the European markets, practices in the United Kingdom appear to be most like that in the UnitedStates.  

## Determinants of Governance (Face-to-Face Interaction)  

We operationalized VC governance or monitoring of ventures as the amount of face-to-face interaction VCs had with venture CEOs. We found some evidence that VCs increase monitoring in response to agency risks, but the results were mixed. Lack of experience on the part of CEOs did not prompt significant additional monitoring as had been predicted. A more potent determinant was how long the VC-CEO pairs worked together; longer relationships mitigated agency concerns and reduced monitoring.Contrary toexpectations. perceived business risk inthe formof VCs'satisfaction with recent venture performance had litle impact on face-to-face interaction.Monitoring was greatest in early stage ventures,indicating that VCs respond to highuncertainty by increased information exchange with CEOs. We measured two types of VC experience and found different patternsforthetwo.Generally speaking.VCs with greaterexperiencein thevenure capitalindustry required less interaction with CEOs, whereas VCs with greater experience in the portfolio company's industry interacted more frequently with CEOs than did VCs without such experience.  

## Determinants of Value Added  

We argued that VCs would most add value to ventures when the venture lacked resources or faced perceived business risks, when the task environment was highly uncertain, and when VCs had great investing and operating experience.Contrary to expectations,VCs added most value to those ventures already performing well.As we had predicted, VCs did add relatively more value when uncertainty was high: e.g.. for ventures in the earliest stages and forventures pursuing innovation strategies. Finally, we found that VCs with operating experience in the venture's focal industry added significantly more value than those with less industry-specific experience. These results are consistent with anecdotalevidence that entrepreneurs havea strong preference for VCs with similar backgrounds as their own. We found no evidence that experience in the venture capital industry contributed significantly to value added.Together, these results suggest that investigations of the social as well as economic dimensions of venture building may prove a fruitful avenue for future study. Overall the results showed that value-added isstrongly related to theamount offace-to-face interaction between VC-CEO pairs and to the number of hours VCs put in on each individual venture.  

## Implications for Venture Capitalists  

The competition for attractive investments is heating up as economies becoine more globalized. Thus,thepressure onventure capitalfrms to operate both efficiently and effectively is also likely to build.It is as yet unclear whetherthe recent trend toward later stage, safer investments will continue, and how those venture capital firms following this path can differentiate thermselves from other sources of capital.Venture capital firms that are able to choose the appropriate bases for determininggovernanceeffort and theappropriate rolesfordeliveringaddedvalue totheirporfolio companies will be those most likely to survive.  

In the largest, most robust markets (ie., the United States and the United Kingdom), more effort is expended by venture capitalists to deliver something of value beyond the money.This sug geststhatthetradeoffpreferredbythosesucceedingistobemoreratherthanlessinvolvedintheir investments.Ourresultsindicate thatVCsclearly economizeon thetime they devotetoinvolvement in theirportfoliocompanies.However,our results also indicate that they dothis at thegreat peril ofproducingvalueinsufficienttojustifythecostof theirproduct.  

## Implications for Entrepreneurs  

Ourfindings provide two important insights forentrepreneurs.First,they show that where and when theyobtainventurecapitalis likely to have animpact on theextent and natureofeffortdeliveredby theirventure capital investors. It appears that on average entrepreneurs receiving venture capital intheUnitedStatesandtheUnitedKingdomwillbemorecloselymonitoredandwillreceivemore value-adding effort from their VCs than will those in France or the Netherlands. Needless to say, entrepreneursshouldconsidertheirpreferencesforlevelandtypeofinvolvementfromtheirinvestors as they consider their choice of partners. In France, for example,VCs put great emphasis on theirfinancialroleincomparisonwithotherroles,buttheycontributemuchlessthanVCselswhere viaotherstrategic,interpersonal,andnetworkingroles.  

Thesecondkeyimplication of ourfindings is that entrepreneursmaybeabletogaugewhat roles VCs will see as most important, when VCs are more or less apt to become involved in their companies,and when they believe they can most add value. Such knowledge may help CEOs anticipate VC activity, be aware of the parameters of VCs' preferences, communicate their own preferences,andnegotiatethetimingandextentofinteraction.Forexample,althoughourresultsindicate that geographic distance significantly limits face-to-face interaction, it appears to have less impact ontheamountofvalueadded.  

## Implications for Researchers  

Much more can be learned about the relative efficiency and effectiveness of alternativegovernance arrangements. Little is known about how formal structures such as contract covenants and board controlworkinconjunctionwithinformaloversightandinteraction.Evenlessisknown about how value is added and how it is best measured. Although this study took a step toward developing a model of the circumstances under which value is added, the theory and its operationalization awaitfurtherdevelopment. $\mathbb{C}1996$ Elsevier Science Inc.  

# INTRODUCTION  

Although venture capital developed in the United States decades before it did elsewhere. the last 15 years have witnessed explosive growth in other venture capital markets, especially those in Europe (Bygrave and Timmons 1992: Ooghe, Manigart, and Fassin 1991). Some researchers have speculated that venture capital markets in Europe have evolved in a pattern similar to that in the United States but have also noted structural differences between U.S. and European venture capital even from the outset (Ooghe et al. 1991: Sapienza. Amason, and Manigart 1994). Of considerable practical importance to venture capitalists (VCs). entrepreneurs, and policy-makers is whether the differences in these markets translate into systematic differences in VCs' efforts to govern their portfolio companies or in their efforts to add value beyond the money they provide. This study therefore was designed to examine the drivers of venture capitalist governance and value added in the United States and in the three largest markets for venture capital in Europe (the United Kingdom, France, and theNetherlands).  

This study should hold practical value for several reasons. First, knowledge of VCs' practices are of interest to entrepreneurs attempting to select the appropriate source of funding. The choice will involve both the type of funding to seek and where and when to seek venture capital funding. Advancements in communication technology and the internationalization of markets appear to make cross-border choices more feasible than ever. For venture capital firms (VCFs), knowledge of others\* practices could prove useful in selecting their domain, planning their portfolio. choosing which competencies to develop. and seting operating policies. Finally. policy-makers could learn from the practices used in various markets how they might enhance VCFs? efforts to fuel the engines of economic growth and success.  

In a recent article, Amar Bhide (1994. p. 139) claimed that "entrepreneurial, privately held companies have taken over as the engines of innovation and job growth." Bhide's view is that the ascension of the entrepreneurial firm in the United States is at least partially the result of public policies that prevent the development of close relationships between outside investors in large. public firms and the firms' inside management. In contrast. private. entreprencurial ventures may establish personal relationships with investors such as VCs who "try to increase companies\* value through counseling and oversight" (p. 138). Indeed, empirical evidence shows that VCs are much more involved in their investments than outside owners in public corporations (Rosenstein 1988). However. evidence also shows that VCs' involvement varies from near passivity to deep involvement (Gorman and Sahlman 1989: MacMillan, Kulow, and Khoylian 1989), and some controversy still exists as to how or even whether VC involvement adds value to new ventures (Rosenstein et al. 1993: Sapienza 1992).  

Studies of VC activity show that VCs are often actively and personally involved in their portfolio companies (Bygrave and Timmons 1992: Fried and Hisrich 1995: Rosenstein 1988). Their involvement includes activities to monitor and provide assistance' to venture management (Gorman and Sahlman 1989; MacMillan et al. 1989). However. whereas such personal contact may afford the opportunity to reduce risks or add value. greater governance may not always be cost effective. Barney et al. (1989. p. 64) point out that VCFs must balance the costs of governance against the benefits. Similarly. Gorman and Sahlman (1989. p. 241) observe that VCs seek to maximize the return on the time they put into ventures. These studies recognize the tradeoffs that VCs make. but neither one explicitly examines how they determine the appropriate level of personal involvement. MacMillan et al. (1989. p. 37) observe that "a relevant issue in need of examination is the opportunity cost of [greater] involvemcnt."  

Because the value of investors personal involvement in investments may vary with circumstances. we designed this study to examine the conditions under which VCs become more involved in their portfolio companies and those under which they believe their involvement is of greatest value to these companies. Recent works in the field have applied economic and organizational theories to model variations in VCF governance (Barney et al. 1989: Sapienza and Gupta 1994). We argue here that to understand VCs choices regarding the amount of effort to expend interacting with CEOs it is important to consider the impact of the delegation of authority to the CEO (an agency issue). expectations regarding returns on investment (a business risk issue). uncertainty regarding the decision-making capacity of the VC-CEO pair (an information-processing issue). and the experience level of the VCs themselves. We also examine how and when VCs add value to their portfolio companies. Because no theory of venture capitalist value added exists. we developed a framework that posits that value added is greatest when ventures are struggling, when uncertainty is great. and when VCs have experience pertinent to the ventures.  

This research represents the broadest comparative study of this nature to date. The use of four markets provides descriptive information of practical value to entrepreneurs. VCFs, and policy-makers and provides insights into the generalizability of the theories forming the framework of the study. A portion of the data we utilize have been reported in prior studies (Sapienza 1992: Sapienza et al. 1994: Sapienza and Timmons 1989), but this study also provides new data and analyses. Differences and overlap between this and past studies are elaborated in the Method section.  

# THEORETICAL FRAMEWORK  

Since Berle and Means's (1932) seminal work. considerable research in both organizational and financial economics has addressed the question of the ability of a firm's owners to monitor and infiuencc the actions of its senior executives (Eisenhardt 1989; Oviatt 1988; Walsh and Seward 1990). Although most of these studies have been conducted in the context of large publicly held firms. Eisenhardt ( 1989) has suggested that these theories could be productively applied also to the governance of smaller, newer firms where there is less dispersion of ownership, where the inherent level of outcome and uncertainty is greater, and where there is a weak market for external control. Thus, closely held firms in developmental stages. cspecially those that have not yet cntered the public market, offer a potentially fruitful arena in which to examine agency and organization theory perspectives on governance and decision-making.  

## Research on Venture Capitalist Involvement in Portfolio Companies  

Studies of VC activity and value added have tended to be descriptive and somewhat atheoretical. Two key studies are those of Gorman and Sahlman (1989) and MacMillan et al. (1989). Gorman and Sahlman found that senior partners in VCFs spend $60\%$ Or more of their time in postinvestment activities and contribute to ventures via financing, strategic and operational planning, management recruiting. and providing a network of contacts. MacMillan et al. (1989) built on Gorman and Sahlman by examining a more elaborate list of 20 activities. Both studies found that VCs rate their strategic activities as the most important. In the MacMillan study. the role of "sounding board" was rated highest: the authors speculated that this might include acting as confidant or mentor, but following Gorman and Sahlman, they did not ask VCs to rate such roles. Gorman and Sahlman found VCs most active in early stage ventures. but MacMillan et al. observed no correlation between activity and context and concluded that VC involvement is primarily a matter of personal preference or inclination.  

VCs in the MacMillan et al. study were generally quite satisfied with their involvement in their portfolio companies. However, whether or not VCs actually add value through involvement remains controversial (Sapienza 1992). For example. MacMillan et al. observed both positive and negative associations between involvement and venture performance: Rosenstein et al. (1993) found that entrepreneurial CEOs rate VCs no more valuable than other outside investors. unless one of the "top 20" VCFs is represented on the board of directors.  

The few studies of European VC activity parallel the U.S. studies but also provide insight into the social roles VCs play. Using the MacMillan et al. (1989) framework, Harrison and Mason (1992) found that entrepreneurs in the United Kingdom rate sounding board and strategic activities as most important and that they depend more on the assistance of VCs than they do on other types of investors. A British Venture Capital Association survey (1992) found that prior to investment, entrepreneurs express a preference for passive financial assistance only, but postinvestment,they rate active, nonfinancial assistance as providing the highest value added. In the Netherlands, Van Wakeren. Van der Werf. Vonk. and Schuit (1989) found that about $60\%$ of entrepreneurs receive important strategic assistance from VCs.and about $20\%$ receive useful networking assistance. Studies in Nordic markets reveal the following: (1) in Finland, the activities of financing and active oversight are rated most important (Ahdekivi 1990): (2) in Sweden, one survey found entrepreneurs rate access to capital., to VC competence. to moral support, and to networks most important (Fredriksen et al. 1990): and (3) another survey in Sweden observed four styles of venture VC involvement: consultancy oriented, mentor oriented, operations oriented, and structure oriented (Landstrom 1991). The two studies in Sweden give explicit recognition to an issue raised, but not explored, in the early U.S. studies: the importance of the personal relationship between the VC and the entrepreneur.  

The importance of the relationship between the VC and the entrepreneurial CEO has also begun to receive attention in the United States. For example, Barney et al. (1994a) observed that unless the entrepreneur is receptive to VC advice, no value added can be achieved through VC involvement, and Fried and Hisrich (1995) went so far as to label the VC a "relationship investor."  

## Determinants of Governance through Interaction  

This new attention to VC-entrepreneur relations provides another way of viewing VC governance. The work of Barney and colleagues (1989. 1994b) shows that VCFs systematically adjust structural governance mechanisms to match agency and business risk. The first of their studies showed that the more the CEO and the managerial team have at stake in the venture and the better the venture's performance in the year of first-round financing, the less VCFs invest in structural governance mechanisms such as presence on the venture's board of directors. The second study found that if new firms experience high returns or if there are obstacles to monitoring, it is more likely that contracts will include covenants that limit venture management's discretion. But structural and contractual devices are crude mechanisms of control (Walsh and Seward 1990). A premise of this study is that VCs influence entrepreneurial behavior through their personal contact with entrepreneurial CEOs. However, because personal contact involves significant costs, we expect that VCs will consciously choose how much effort to expend depending upon their experience and their perceptions of the agency risk, business risk, and uncertainty inherent in the situation.  

Personal interactions with CEOs may serve several purposes for the VC: they allow the VC to become personally familiar with what is going on in the business. to understand how the CEO operates and thinks, to build rapport, and to influence decisions. Nonetheless. because time is a precious resource for VCs (Gorman and Sahlman 1989) and because entrepreneurs may resent excessive intrusion (Sapienza 1992), VCs will seek to limit face-to-face contact to the extent possible (Barney et al. 1989). Thus. efficiency is an underlying principle in our governance hypotheses. Given that general partners are involved on average in six or more portfolio companies (Gorman and Sahlman 1989). efficiency of oversight appears a critical issue for VCFs (Lerner 1995).  

### Impact of Agency Risks on VC-CEO Interaction  

We expect that VCs will vary their personal contact with CEOs depending on the agency risk inherent in the context. We define agency risk as the risk that CEOs (agents) will take actions contrary to the wishes of their VCs (Jensen and Meckling 1976). Such risks would be higher either when CEOs have greater incentive to pursue self-serving behavior at the expense of venture outcomes (Barney et al. 1989) or when VCs lack complete faith in the judgments of the CEOs (Sapienza and Gupta 1994). Because CEOs generally hold significant equity stakes in their ventures and have great incentive to maximize venture outcomes (Sapienza and Gupta, 1994), we focus here on agency risks emanating from VC uncertainty regarding CEO judgment rather than on those associated with managerial opportunism.  

As noted by Sapienza and Gupta (1994), although VCFs expend great effort to ensure the quality of venture management before investment, the variety of demands on the CEO make it virtually impossible that any CEO or management team will be “"perfectly" competent in all situations. Some CEOs may have great technical experience, whereas others understand the venture building process thoroughly. VCs' continuing doubts are reflected in both Ruhnka and Young's (1987) finding that managerial competence is among the greatest of VCs' concerns and Gorman and Sahlman's finding that VCs overwhelmingly attribute venture failure to managerial incompetence: indeed, Gorman and Sahlman speculate that the nature of the venture capital process itself requires that VCs be constantly vigilant with regard to potential managerial weaknesses. Thus, a critical paradox arises: VCs must both support and question management decisions.  

In short, it appears likely that VCs will expend additional effort to interact on a faceto-face basis when they fear that a CEO's competence poses a threat to the venture's success. This reasoning is consistent with Fiet's (1995) view that, postinvestment, VCs manage agency risks through face-to-face interaction, a form of contact that provides an opportunity to gather information and to create a personal understanding of the business and its people. However. the greater VCs' confidence in CEOs' decision-making, the less their incentive to incur the costs of close, personal governance. Thus, we offer our first hypothesis:  

Hl: The higher the agency risks, the greater will be the face-to-face interaction between the VC and the CEO.  

### Impact of Perceived Business Risk on VC-CEO Interaction  

Barney et al. (1989, p. 64) define business risk for VCFs as "the uncertainty associated with obtaining returns on an investment in a new firm due to that firm's competitive environment." They show that as such uncertainties increase,VCFs increase the elaborateness of their governance mechanisms to protect against adverse outcomes. Consistent with their work, we expect that VCs will also increase face-to-face governance of the CEO when business risk is high.  

Because the extent of business risk cannot be perfectly anticipated in advance, VCs will adjust their level of monitoring to fit the perceived progress of the ventures. We posit that when ventures are exceeding expectations, VCs will be less inclined to be involved. As an example, one of the VCs we interviewed said, "When the venture is really moving, the best thing you can do is to just stay out of the way of the freight train." On the other hand, it seems likely that when VCs believe the ventures are doing very poorly they have a fiduciary responsibility to find out why. Whereas VCs' incentive to expend the time and effort required for face-to-face interaction with CEOs is low for ventures meeting or exceeding targets. VCs of poorly performing ventures are likely to become more involved. if only to determine whether or not venture management should be changed. Thus. we offer our second hypothesis:  

$H2$ : The higher the perceived business risk faced by the venture, the greater will be the face-to-face interaction between the venture capitalist and the venture CEO.  

### Impact of Uncertainty on VC-CEO Interaction  

VC oversight of ventures involves not only the monitoring of CEOs' decisions but also the direct involvement of VCs in making strategic decisions (Gorman and Sahlman 1989: Lerner 1995: Rosenstein 1988). Sapienza and Gupta (1994. p. 1622) argued that the informationprocessing perspective (Galbraith 1973) could provide useful insights as to why VCs might seek more or less interaction in assisting CEOs in decision-making. The value that this perspective adds is that it provides insights as to why VCs might vary monitoring efforts even when there are no conflicts of interest among decision-makers. The information-processing theory holds that the structure of joint decision-making depends upon the level of uncertainty (i.e., the gap between the information necessary to make effective decisions and the information already possessed by the decision-makers [Galbraith 1973]). Specifically. it suggests that decision-makers will seek cost-efficient means to reduce uncertainty.  

From an information-processing perspective, two basic alternatives exist for reducing uncertainty: decision-makers can reduce goals or they can increase their information-processing capacity. VCFs do not invest money in high risk ventures with the idea of obtaining modest but certain returns. Because VCFs seek high returns on their capital (Bygrave and Timmons 1992), it is the second of these two rationales that is apropos to most VC-CEO pairs. Thus, we expect that as the uncertainty facing ventures increases. VCs will attempt to increase ventures' information-processing capacity by stepping up their face-to-face interaction with the CEO. This expectation can be stated formally as follows:  

$H3$ : The higher the uncertainty facing the venture. the greater will be the face-toface interaction between the venture capitalist and the venture CEO.  

### Inpact of VC experience on VC-CEO interaction.  

Directly bearing on the issue of the amount of uncertainty facing the venture is the information-processing capacity of the VC-CEO pair responsible for many of the key decisions facing the venture. All other things being equal. we expect that the amount of information VCs bring to the table will increase directly with their experience as venture capitalists or in the venture's focal industry. Further. we also expect that greater experience will be associated with greater effciency in information processing and decision-making. Thus. for highly experienced VCs, less face-to-face interaction should be required to produce decisions of the same quality as those produced by less experienced VCs (Sapienza 1989: Williamson 1975). Given that VCs will seek to economize on the time consumed in the direct governance of ventures ( Barney et al. 1989; Fiet 1995). these arguments suggest that experienced VCs are more likely to be able to economize and still adequately perform their fiduciary responsibilities. These expectations can be formally stated as the following hypothesis:  

$H4.$ The greater VCs' experience. the less frequent will be the interaction between the venture capitalist and the venture CEO.  

## Determinants of Value Added  

Theories of how and when VCs most add value to the ventures they fund are not well-developed. We take steps toward a theory of investor value added by developing expectations and testing them on our data set. We will rely on the information-processing perspective (Galbraith 1973) as the basis for making predictions regarding when VCs most add value to the ventures in which they invest. Our central thesis is that when CEOs lack sufficient information or information-processing capacity or when they perceive great information potential in their VCs they will seek the assistance of their VCs. Three broad conditions are expected to increase VCs' value added: (1) when venture capacities fall short of venture "needs." (2) when the venture faces great uncertainties regarding what the optimal strategies are or how best to implement the chosen strategies, and (3) when the VCs themselves appear to offer a significant source of valuable information for the venture. These views are also consistent with resource dependency theory (Pfeffer and Salancik 1978): VCs will be most valued when they are able to reduce critical uncertainties for the venture (Bygrave and Timmons 1992). This greater contribution will result not only becauseVCs may help substantively in the reduction of uncertainties. but also because the CEO is likely to ask for more help in these situations and to be more receptive to the advice given by the VC (Barney et al. 1994a).  

### Impact of Venture Needs on Value Added  

Lerner (1995. p. 301) argued recently that VCs provide the greatest assistance to new ventures "when the need for oversight is greatlest]." On the surface. this view may appear a near tautology. Surely, it makes great sense to argue that a venture can most benefit from outside advice when it is "neediest." Won't the venture benefit most from VC involvement when the venture management team is incomplete or inexperienced or when the venture is struggling to survive? Deeper consideration of the issues, however, suggests that the converse is possible. Sapienza et al. (1994) speculated that VCs might follow "home-run" strategies, preferring to put greater effort and resources into ventures promising the greatest payoff. Similarly. experienced venture CEOs and management teams less in need of outside assistance may be more capable of evaluating and leveraging the input of their VCs.  

If we view the CEO-VC pair as a key decision-making unit for the venture, the information-processing perspective implies that as the venture's information-processing capacity falls below that required foreffective decisions. VCs will be motivated toincrease their input. Inexperienced CEOs are likely to have fewer contacts to critical information and to be subject to greater equivocality regarding cause and effect relations than are more experienced CEOs. The duration of the VC-CEO relationship should also have had an impact on the amount of value added during any given interval of time: the less time the venture had been in the portfolio, the less likely that the venture will have absorbed all knowledge. reputation. and network benefits offered by VCF-backing. Thus. the greatest value added probably occurs earlier on in the relationship. Finally, ventures seen to be performing poorly may attract the greatest concern of investors fearful of realizing a total loss on investment. An additional reason to expect that VCs' value will be greatest under these circumstances is that entrepreneurs may be more receptive to VCs' input when they perceive a greater need for assistance. In summary. we expect value added to be high when CEOs are less experienced, when the relationship is older. and when the venture is seen as performing poorly. These arguments lead to the following hypothesis:  

H5: The greater the needs of the venture, the greater will be the value added of the VC's involvement.  

### Impact of Uncertainty on Value Added  

Sapienza and Gupta (1994) found that the greater the uncertainties facing the venture, the greater was their face-to-face interaction. They attributed this finding both to the increased difficulty of assessing outcome causes in highly uncertain situations and to the desire on the part of both parties to improve decision-making. This interpretation is consistent with the view that a viable option for decision-makers facing great uncertainty is to increase lateral relations (Galbraith 1973). An assumption of this perspective is that decision-makers are limited in their rational capacities. The extent of limitations on individual decision-makers is a direct function of the complexity and novelty of the problems they face. When CEOs face very simple. stable conditions, the cost of interacting with outside advisors may exceed the benefits. However, we expect that as problem complexity and novelty rise, so too will the value of interacting with outside advisors. Thus, we offer the following hypothesis:  

H6: The greater the uncertainty facing the venture, the greater will be the value added of the VC's involvement.  

### Impact of VC Experience on Value Added  

VCs' experience may be the most critical factor determining the amount of value added received through interaction. As was the case with venture need, the expected impact of VCs' experience on value added may appear obvious. Clearly, VCs who have financed and monitored hundreds of new ventures, have started some of their own, or who have years of experience in the ventures' industries are likely to have more to offer CEOs than those who have limited experience. Further. is it not likely that CEOs will be more receptive to the views of VCs with great experience? Indeed. we expect VC experience to be positively related to value added, but we also believe some caveats are in order.  

Implicit in most of our arguments has been the view that greater effort on the part of VCs is associated with greater value added. However, earlier we argued that experienced VCs could satisfy their fiduciary responsibilities with less effort. Thus, the possibility exists that experienced VCs will interact less with CEOs and will therefore add less value to the ventures than inexperienced VCs. Anecdotal evidence suggests that if VCs greater experience is as a financier of new ventures (i.e., as a venture capitalist) rather than as a practitioner in the venture's industry, the danger of resentment on the part of the CEO is great (Sapienza 1989). Indeed, we heard complaints in interviews with both VCs and entrepreneurs about VCs who were "financial MBA-types" or who "never started any business of their own."  

Although the above dangers exist. we expect that VCs who survive to become experienced are those who are aware of these perceptions and are able to manage involvement so as to contribute value beyond the money provided. Rosenstein et al. (1993) found that VCs from the top U.S. VCFs were perceived as adding more value than other outsiders. The importance of reputation and experience are implicit in their arguments and supported by their findings. In summary, we expect that VCs with experience in the venture's industry will have a great deal to offer because of their understanding of the business, whereas VCs with a great deal of experience as venture capitalists will have much to offer because of their understanding of the venture development process. Further, though this latter group may be especially inclined to try to economize on effort, they will not do so at the expense of offering more than enough to justify the price entrepreneurs pay for their investment. Thus, our final hypothesis is as follows:

# INDUSTRY CONDITIONSIN THE FOUR COUNTRIES  

Industry structure and investment patterns within countries may contribute to differences in how involved VCs are in their portfolio companies. Although Europe is one of the fastest growing venture capital markets in the world (Bygrave and Timmons 1992). relatively little empirical work has examined the European venture capital industry (Ooghe et al. 1991). Ooghe et al. observe that not only are the venture capital industries in the United States and Europe structurally different from one another, but that significant differences also exist among markets within Europe. For example, VCFs' sources of funds, their preferences for stage and industry sector, the fiscal climate, and even the extent of VCF market dominance may vary on a country-by-country basis. Therefore, we will briefly describe the venture capital markets in the four countries at time the data collection was done (early 1988 in the United States and mid-1992 in Europe).  

Readers should keep in mind not only the difference in the time period of data collection but also differences in terminology across settings. Bygrave and Timmons (1992. p. 73) caution that definitions of venture capital vary even within countries, much less on a worldwide basis; for example, they point to the fact that what 3i (the dominant VCF in the UK) would call a "start-up" would not be considered one in the United States. Table 1 presents statistics on capital raised and invested in each market and the percentage of funds invested by VCF type.  

Whereas the venture capital industry in the United States was larger and more developed than that of any other individual country. figures show that by 1988 Europe had caught up with and surpassed the United States in terms of funds raised and invested annually (Bygrave and Timmons 1992: Ooghe et al. 1991). The European venture capital industry reached its peak in 1989 in terms of total new funds raised for venture capital (5.8 billion ECU): this stabilized at 4.2 billion ECU in 1991 and 1992. The yearly amount invested, however. grew slowly in Europe: 4.3 billion ECU in 1989 to 4.7 billion ECU in 1992 (EVCA 1993. p. 63). The European VC industry clearly came to maturity in 1992: divestments in 1992. measured at cost. totalled 2.3 billion ECU or $17\%$ higher than in 191. One major difference from the U.S. venture capital industry is that trade sales in Europe remain the most important means of divestment: they account for 41 % of 1992 divestments. whereas public offerings accounted for only 17% of divestments in 1992 and under 10% in 1991 (EVCA 1993, pp. 47-48). Europe lacks active IPO markets as exit routes for venture capital investments (Leleux and Manigart 1994).  

In absolute numbers, the United Kingdom, France, and the Netherlands were the largest venture capital markets in Europe. Table 1 shows that the United Kingdom held a healthy lead over France, which in turn was a much larger market than the Netherlands. The venture capital industry in Europe comprised four distinct groups of organizations (EVCA 1993): (1) independent firms: (2) captive organizations, part of larger financial institutions: (3) semicaptive organizations, partially owned by larger (financial) institutions but operating independently: and (4) public firms.-In the United States. the most common way of classifying VCFs was as private firms. SBICs, and corporate subsidiaries ( Pratt's Guide to Venture Capital Sources 1988). In 1992. almost two-thirds of the investments were made by independent organizations in the Netherlands. compared with $54.7\%$ in the United Kingdom, and only $32.3\%$ in France. Whereas the U.S. market in 1988 was also dominated by large. private VCFs ( $81\%$ of capital under management in 1989 was held by private VCFs. and $14\%$ of all VCFs controlled $59\%$ of the funds [Timmons and Sapienza 1992]), no one firm in the United States held the dominating presence that 3i did in the United Kingdom (Ooghe et al. 1991).  

In 1992, the amount of funds raised by VCFs had decreased slightly in the Netherlands and in France. but had remained relatively constant in the United Kingdom (EVCA 1993). In the United States, the $\$4.2$ billion raised in 1987 was a high point. However. Black Monday in October of that year marked a turning point for venture capital in the United States: only $\$2.9$ billion was raised in 1988, beginning a downward spiral that reached its nadir in 1991 at $\$1.3$ billion before rebounding to $\$3.8$ billion in 1994 ( Pratt's Guide to Venure Capital Sources 1995). Table 1 indicates the amount of venturc capital raised and invested in 1992 in the four markets as a percentage of each country's gross domestic product: these comparisons provide one view of the relative importance of venture capital in each country's econOmy. As may be observed, venture capital raised and invested in the United Kingdom $(0.15\%$ and $0.23\%$ . respectively) represents a much larger proportion of that country's economy than does venture capital elsewhere. Although representing the single largest market in absolute terms. the U.S. market for venture capital is the smallest relative to its overall economy.  

The most important sources of funds for independent VCFs in the United Kingdom and in the Netherlands were the pension funds and insurance companies. whereas institutional investors were relatively absent from the venture capital market in France. Funds raised from institutional sources in France tended to come from abroad (EVCA 1993). Moreover. in France, financial institutions and banks dominated the industry by setting up captive and semicaptive venture capital organizations. In the Netherlands. the government directly invested in venture capital; this was not the case in the United Kingdom or in France. A new phenomenon in the United Kingdom was that funds were increasingly being raised for investing in foreign markets, especially targeted for southern Europe.

Pension funds were the dominant suppliers of capital in the United States during the period of the study $(46\%)$ , whereas the remaining capital was raised from foreign investors $(14\%)$ . endowments and foundations $(12\%)$ 、corporations $(11\%)$ , insurance companies $(9\%)$ . and individuals and families $(8\%)$ : banks could not invest in venture capital in the United States (Timmons and Sapienza 1992).  

There was much less investment in early stage and high tech businesses in European countries than in the United States (Murray 1991: Ooghe et al. 1991). Management buyouts and buyins accounted for almost two-thirds of the amount invested in the United Kingdom; in the Netherlands and France, expansion stage financing and replacement capital was prevalent. Among the European countries of this study, only in the Netherlands was as much as $8\%$ of investment going to very early stage companies, whereas the figure was about 28% in the United States (Timmons and Sapienza 1992): again. however, differences in terminology pose a challenge to precise comparison.  

Compared with all the countries in Europe. the United Kingdom and France have the best environmental conditions (government incentives, tax structures. etc.) for venture capital, followed by the Netherlands (Tyebjee and Vickery 1988: Roure, Keeley. and Van der Heyden 1990). It is difficult to compare European fiscal policies directly with those in the United States, but some researchers have concluded that domestic VCFs in the United States are adversely impacted (in comparison with foreign entry) by fiscal policy (Timmons and Sapienza1992).  

Overall, the U.K. market appears most similar with respect to size. maturity, and dominant type of VCF to that of the United States. This is not surprising given that the U.K. market developed sooner than other European markets. However, vast differences between the two exist in terms of funding preferences and governance styles. Within Europe, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom look alike with respect to the industry structure. whereas the Netherlands and France look alike with respect to investment patterns. At the time of survey administration in the United States, the market for IPOs had just experienced a setback reflected in the severe drop in venture capital funds raised. In contrast, the European venture capital industry was relatively stable at the time the survey was administered, and European VCFs tended to invest in later stage, safer ventures (Bygrave and Timmons1992).  

# METHOD  

The data reported in this study were obtained in two separate collection efforts, the second a follow-up and replication of parts of the first (U.S.) study. The U.S. data were collected in 1987-1988: the procedures, sample, and methods involved in this study have been reported in detail elsewhere (Sapienza 1992: Sapienza and 1994: Sapienza and Timmons 1989). In brief. the U.S. study involved extensive interviewing of VCs and CEOs of their portfolio companies and follow-up questionnaires based on the interviews and prior empirical work. The personal interviews created a very high response rate ( $85\%$ and $80\%$ ,respectively) and allowed us to develop our surveys: they also provided an in-depth view of the nature of the economic and personal relationships involved. Questionnaire responses were received from VCs on 65 of their portfolio companies: matched responses were obtained from CEOs of 51 of these ventures. High correspondence between VCs and CEOs regarding the importance and value of venture capitalist involvement in the ventures as well as venture performance allowed the responses to be combined as reliable, valid measures for 51 ventures; only these 51 were used in the earlier studies. The study reported here includes all 65 responsesfromVCs.  

Because of the interrater reliability evident in the first study and because resources prevented obtaining matched responses of VC-CEO pairs in the three European countries, the follow-up study obtained survey responses from VCs only. However. this procedure allowed us to survey the entire target population. A slightly modified version of the U.S. questionnaire was prepared in English. translated into Dutch and French, and sent to all known British, French, and Dutch VCs in early 1992 (translations were retranslated into English to ensure correspondence of meaning). VCFs were identified using membership lists of national and European venture capital associations. trade journals, and Venture Economics' Guide to European Venture Capital Sources. We sent one survey to each of the VCFs identified in the three countries. Responses were 76 in the United Kingdom ( $43\%$ response rate), 43 in France( $25\%$ response), and 37 in the Netherlands ( $40\%$ response), 156 in all. Analyses of the characteristics of nonresponding VCFs show no significant differences from responding VCFs; thus, the probability of nonresponse bias appears minimal.  

In the United States. personal interviews allowed us to encourage VCs to fill out surveys on two portfolio companies. preferably one doing well and one doing not so well. This procedure helped to limit possible sampling bias. In Europe, questionnaires were mailed to VCs who were asked to pick one venture only, but requirements that the VCs personally served on the boards and that the VCF's investment was at least two years old restricted their choice. The means of the performance rating in all countries was around the middle of the scale and their standard deviations were large enough to suggest that no systematic favoring of ventures by performance occurred. Table 2 presents descriptive statistics on the VCFs and portfolio companies in our sample.  

## Measures for Tests of Hypotheses  

### Dependent Variables  

The central concepts in this study are the governance effort expended by VCs and the roles by which they add value to their portfolio companies. As has been noted by Rosenstein (1988) and Gorman and Sahlman (1989). among others, VCs influence and help direct venture efforts through personal involvement at board meetings and other informal interactions with CEOs. Accordingly, we have measured process governance (Sapienza 1994) as the frequency of face-to-face interaction in VC-CEO pairs: ( $1=$ less than once a quarter; $2=$ once a quarter: $3=$ once a month: $4=$ twice a month; $5\approx$ once a week; $6=$ twice a week: $7=$ every day).  

To measure value added we asked VCs to rate the importance (on a scale from $1=$ not important at all, to $5=$ of great importance) of the different roles they assumed with regard to the venture. These roles were derived from prior research (e.g., Gorman and Sahlman 1989; MacMillan et al. 1989) and our own field work. VCs also rated their effectiveness in carrying out these roles (from $1=$ not at all effective, to $10\:=\:$ extremely effective). By multiplying the importance by the effectiveness rating we derived a measure of value added for each role (with a possible range of $1=$ no value added to $50=$ very high value added). The overall value added then was the average score across the eight roles. Table 3 presents summary statistics on VC effort. VC-CEO interaction, individual value-added roles, and overall value added of VCs.  

### Independent Variables Predicting Governance  

We used three indicators of agency risk, one of business risk, four of uncertainty. and two of VC experience to test our four hypotheses (H1-H4) regarding VC governance. As explained below. geographic distance was also used as a control variable in tests of both governance and value added. The means and standard deviations of these indicators appear in Table 4.  

#### Agency Risk  

Agency risk was measured by three variables: (1) the CEO's years of experience in the focal industry, (2) the CEO's previous start-up experience (coded $\because0^{\cdot\cdot}$ if the CEO had no prior start-up experience, "1" if he/she had), and (3) the number of years the venture had been in the VCF's portfolio. We expected that VCs would perceive agency risks as high when: (1) the CEO had relatively few years' experience in the venture's industry, (2) the CEO had relatively few years\* experience in new firms, and (3) when the venture had been in the

Using years in the portfolio as a measure of agency risk is consistent both with Larson's ( 1992) argument that social contracting can replace economic contracts over time and with Williamson's (1975) observation that over time repeated interaction limits opportunism. The three variables we chose represent agency risks emanating from the delegation of decision-making authority. rather than from goal conflict. Significant negative coefficients on these variables in our governance equations would support H1.  

Consistent with Barney et al. (1989). we measured perceived business risk as VCs' satisfaction with the venture's recent performance.
