#### Uncertainty  

Uncertainty (defined as the gap between the information possessed by decision-makers and the information needed to make effective decisions [Galbraith 1973]) was operationalized by venture stage and by three measures of innovation. Sapienza and Gupta (1994) argued that uncertainty is at its height in the earliest stages of venture development. Because terminology and definitions of financing stage vary across and even within countries (Bygrave and Timmons 1992), we opted for a dichotimization of this variable ( $0=$ earlystage, $1=$ late stage) to simplify interpretation and minimize the probability of observing spurious relationships. Our expectation that uncertainty is highest in early stage venture means that we were predicting a negative coefficient for the stage variable (H3).  

Zaltman, Duncan. and Holbek (1973) suggested that uncertainty among decision-makers about cause-effect relationships increases as the level of innovation increases. Therefore. in order to capture uncertainty emanating from cause-effect uncertainty we used three measures of innovation consistent with the three types of innovation suggested by Zaltman et al. (1973): technical, product, and marketing innovation. VCs were asked to rate ventures' level of innovation relative to their competitors' on each of these three dimensions of innovation. For each. we coded responses as $\cdots0^{\cdot\cdot}$ if the innovation was rated equal to or less than competitors. "1" if rated greater or much greater than competitors. Because greater uncertainty here is indicated by higher numbers. positive values on these three indicators would supportH3.  

In Europe, we acquired two measures of VCs experience: (1) VC experiencc was indicated by VCs' years of experience in the venture capital industry, and (2) VCs focal industry experience was indicated by their years' operating experience in the venture's industry. In the U.S. survey, the original measures had been slightly different: VC experience had been coded as $"0"$ if VCs had worked in the venture capital industry for fewer than five years and \*1" if it was five or more: VCs' focal industry experience had been indicated by the number of rounds of financing the VC had worked with the venture in the focal industry. Significant negative coefficients for these VC experience variables would support H4.  

### Independent Variables Predicting VC Value Added  

All independent variables predicting face-to-face interaction were also used to predict valueadded; the grouping of the variables varied slightly to reflect the constructs in the final three hypotheses. H5 predicts that VCs add most value when ventures are neediest; venture needs were assumed to be greatest when CEOs were inexperienced, when the venture had been in the portfolio a longer time. and when venture performance was perceived as being poor. H6 predicts that value added will be higher when uncertainty is greater. Early stage ventures face greater uncertainties regarding demand. pricing, product requirements, and channels of distribution. among others. Thus, H6 implies a negative relationship with venture stage but a positive relationship with the three types of innovation measured here. Finally. VCs' experience is predicted in H7 to be positively related to venture experience. As described in the prior sections, we measured experience as a venture capitalist and experience in the focal industry because the two represent two fundamentally different but potentially important ways in which VCs can add value.  

## Tests of Governance and Value-Added Hypotheses  

The governance hypotheses and the expectations for value added were examined via ordinary least squares multiple regressions in which the 10 predictor variables and the control variable (i.e. geographic distance) were regressed against face-to-face interaction (see Table 5) and value added (see Table 6).  

These tests were first conducted for each country separately as theoretical and empirical literature have indicated that significant differences exist between the United States and Europe and within the European venture capital market (Ooghe et al. 1991). Results within the United States appear in column 5 in both tables. Results within the United Kingdom, France. and the Netherlands appear in columns 1-3, respectively. We also ran tests with aggregated European data. using the United Kingdom as the base case and entering dummy variables for France and the Netherlands: these results appear in column 4. Aggregating the data in this way allowed us to see more directly how each compares with the other countries in Europe and to see how the overall models worked in the United States versus Europe. Pooling the U.S. and European data would not have been advisable given the differences in timeframe and terminology.  

In conducting the regression analyses, we dropped all cases with missing data. Thus, missing data accounted for differences in the \*Ns" across our tables. We included geographic distance (travel time for the VC to the venture) as a control variable in analyses because it may have had an impact on the cost of involvement (Lerner 1995) or the probability of opportunistic behavior (Barney et al. 1994b).

## Additional Analyses  

Tests for minimum tolerance limits indicate that multicollinearity does not pose a significant threat to interpretation of the regression results. As mentioned earlier. the matched pair sampling procedure used in the original study indicated a high level of interrater reliability between VCs and entrepreneurs. This correspondence reduces, but does not eliminate. concern about common method variance. which might hinder the interpretability of the data. Because in the present study we used only a single data source for responses, we used an analytic method suggested by Podsakoff and Organ (1986) to examine the extent to which common method variance might undermine the validity of our data. We examined the factor structure of the criterion and predictor variables. If only a single factor emerged or if the variance in the data were largely explained by a single factor. the threat of common method variance would be high. For our data, at least four factors emerged in each country with eigenvalues greater than 1. and the largest single factor in any country explained only $22\%$ of the variance; the same pattern also held when all data were pooled. Thus. common method variance did not appear to be a significant problem for our data set.  

# RESULTS  

Table 2 indicates the number and type of VCFs by country, the size of ventures boards of directors (including the number of inside members), and several of the characteristics of the ventures themselves. Consistent with what has been observed in prior literature (e.g.. Timmons and Sapienza 1992). our sample shows a much higher percentage of early stage ventures in the United States $(43\%)$ than in the United Kingdom $(27\%)$ , France $(14\%)$ . or the Netherlands $(9\%)$ . Because economic sectors were measured differently in the two studies, we cannot make direct comparisons of ventures by economic sector between the United States and Europe. Manufacturing, computer-related. and consumer products account for $56\%$ of the sample in the United Kingdom. $49\%$ in France, and $35\%$ in the Netherlands. Biotech, chemicals. and electronics make up $32\%$ of the ventures in the Netherlands. but only $14\%$ of those in the United Kirgdom and France. Across the sample, the percentage of CEOs with prior start-up experience is between $30\%$ and $40\%$ . In all four countries ventures pursue greater relative product innovation than they do technical or marketing innovation.  

Table 3 indicates that VC-CEO pairs averaged meeting slightly more than once a month. Our interviews showed that in the U.S. board meetings occur about once a month in very early stage ventures and quarterly as the venture reaches greater maturity. Thus. given that the majority of ventures in this sample are late stage ventures, the rate of faceto-face interaction in this sample probably indicates that VC-CEO pairs meet informally with some regularity. Table 3 also shows how many hours VCs devote yearly to each portfolio company. Clearly. VCs in the United States and the United Kingdom expend greater effort in monitoring and assisting their portfolio companies than do those in France and the Netherlands; this observation is true both in terms of the frequency of personal contact and the total number of hours expended on each venture.  

Table 3 also displays a remarkable consistency across all four countries in regards to the value added through strategic. interpersonal, and networking roles. These roles are roughly equivalent to what Fredriksen et al. (1990. p. 251) labeled "competence, support, and access to networks." Generally speaking, VCs see themselves as providing the greatest value through their strategic roles and the least through their networking assistance. These results help to clarify how VCs add value to their portfolio companies. Much of the previous literature has failed to recognize the interpersonal dimension of VC-venture partnerships. Our results indicate clearly that the social or interpersonal roles of venture capitalists are a significant element in the functioning of these partnerships. In the United States and the United Kingdom, value added through interpersonal roles is close to the level of value added in strategic roles, whereas in France and the Netherlands the value added of interpersonal roles is closer to the less important networking roles.  

U.S. VCs see themselves as offering the greatest value added overall. The closeness of the average ratings between the United Kingdom and the Netherlands may be somewhat misleading in that VCs in the Netherlands place greater emphasis on networking roles. roles seen as least critical across the sample. In general. perceptions of value added correspond with effort expended ( hours devoted to the portfolio company and frequency of interaction ). Table 4 indicates that CEOs average between 11 and 13 years of experience. Venture performance ratings in all four countries are near the midpoint, indicating that the sample is not biased toward either high or low performing ventures.  

## Governance Results  

Table 5 presents the results of regression cquations testing our four governance hypotheses. As may be observed, face-to-face governance in the United States is much better explained by the factors examincd in this study than is such governance in Europe. Specifically. the adjusted $\mathbf{R}^{?}$ for the model in the United States is $54\%$ : it ranges between $13\%$ and $18\%$ in the European countries. and $18\%$ Overall for Europe. We will first present the results comparing the U.S. and the pooled European sample: we will conclude with a summary of the impact of country on face-to-face interaction.  

### Agency Risk and Governance  

H1 (face-to-face interaction is greater when agency risks are high) receives mixed support. Less CEO experience is not related to more face-to-face contact. CEOs' industry experience is unrelated to VC-CEO contact both in the United States and in the pooled European sample; in France, contrary to expectations. VCs more frequently visit CEOs with grcater industry experience. Further. in the overall European sample (and in the Netherlands and France). CEOs with more start-up experience are visited by VCs significantly more frequently than less experienced CEOs. In the United States, the relationship is negative. as predicted, but is not significant. As predicted. fewer years in the VCF's portfolio are associated with significantly greater face-to-face contact in France and the United States. This relationship is relatively weak even in these countries and does not hold for the overall sample in Europe.  

### Business Risk and Governance  

H2 (face-to-face interaction is greatcr when business risk is high) is not supported. Venture performance is unrelated to governance in the United States and in the pooled sample in Europe: contrary to our prediction, it is positively related to VC-CEO interaction in the Netherlands.  

### Uncertainty and Governance  

H3 predicted that greater uncertainty leads to greater governance effort. This prediction is strongly supported in terms of venture stage but is not supported in terms of innovation. Earlier stage ventures receive significantly more face-to-face interaction both in the United  

States and in Europe. It should be noted that this result holds despite controlling for the number of years the ventures have been in the portfolio. All three subsamples in Europe show the same strong negative relationship; in France, the relationship is also as expected but is not significant. The results do not indicate increased governance in response to innovation as predicted in the hypothesis. For the pooled European sample, none of the three measures of innovation are significantly related to VC-CEO contact. In the United States, only marketing innovation is related to face-to-face interaction, and it is in the opposite direction of the one predicted. Further, whereas marketing innovation in France and product innovation in the Netherlands are related to face-to-face interaction in the manner predicted. both technical and product innovation in France are in the opposite direction as that predicted.  

### VC Experience and Governance  

As we predicted in H4. VCs' experience in the venture capital industry is negatively related to face-to-face interaction in both Europe and the United States. However. contrary to expectations. VCs' experience in the new venture's industry is positively associated with governance in both the United States and the pooled European sample. The strong relationships in the UK between VCs' experience in the venture's industry and personal contact appear to be driving the significant results in the pooled sample. Thus, H4 receives mixed support.  

### Distance and Governance  

As might be expected. geographic distance appears to reduce face-to-face contact; this effect is significant in the United States. in the pooled European sample, and in the United Kingdom.  

### Governance by Country within Europe  

The significant negative coefficients in column 4 of Table 5 for the country dummy variables $(\mathrm{FR}=-0.693;\mathrm{NL}=-0.647)$ indicate that when compared with the United Kingdom and the Netherlands, VCs in France have significantly less face-to-face interaction with CEOs: and when compared with the United Kingdom and France, VCs in the Netherlands have significantly less interaction with CEOs. In other words, country has significant explanatory power for interaction in Europe. An inspection of Table 3 shows that what this means is that VCs in the UK interact on a face-to-face basis with their CEOs more frequently than do the VCs in the other two countries. As mentioned earlier. VCs in the United States and the United Kingdom appear to take a much more active governance role than do those in France and the Netherlands.  

## Value-Added Results  

Table 6 presents the results of equations regressing value added against indicators of venture need. uncertainty. and VC experience. Table 6 shows that as with governance efforts, the value-added efforts of VCs in the United States is better explained than are those of European VCs. However, in this instance the difference is not as dramatic. Specifically, the adjusted ${\mathbf{R}}^{2}$ for the model in the United States is $35\%$ , whereas it ranges between $15\%$ and $25\%$ in the European countries and is $20\%$ for the pooled sample in Europe.  

### VentureNeed andValue Added  

For the most part, H5 (that venture need is positively related to VC value added) is not supported. CEOs' industry experience is unrelated to value added in the United States and in Europe, including the subsamples in each country. As anticipated, CEOs' start-up experience is negatively related to value added in the United States, but the relationship is not significant. Start-up experience is marginally positively related to value added for the pooled sample in Europe. a result opposite that expected. Second, as predicted, fewer years in the portfolio are negatively related to value added in the Netherlands. However, this relationship is marginal, and years in the portfolio are not related to value added in the United States Or the pooled European sample. Finally, venture performance is positively related to value added both in the pooled European sample and in the United States. This result is contrary to our expectations.  

### Uncertainty andValue Added  

Our results indicate consistent support for the prediction that value added will be greatest when uncertainty is high (H6). As predicted, a strong negative relationship exists between venture stage and value added in the United States. No relationship exists between stage and value added for the pooled European sample, but this result is complex. The expected negative relationship between stage and value added is present in the Netherlands. but this is offset by an unexpected positive relationship in France. Interestingly, French VCs appear to interact more frequently with early stage ventures (see Table 5) but perceive greater contributions in later stage investments.  

As anticipated, the results show a positive relationship between venture innovation and value added in the pooled European sample, but innovation is not related to value added in the United States. Value-added increases significantly with increases in technical innovation and marketing innovation in the pooled sample for Europe. These results appear to be largely due to strong relationships between innovation and value added in the United Kingdom. Product innovation has no impact on value-added in any of the four countries.  

### VC Experience and Value Added  

H7, predicting that value added will be directly related to VC experience. receives mixed support. Contrary to expectations, VCs' venture capital industry experience is negatively related to value added in the pooled European sample; it is not related to perceptions of value added in the United States. As we predicted. however, VCs' experience in the venture's industry is positively associated with value added both in the United States and in the pooled European sample. Further, both types of VC experience are positively related to value added in the United Kingdom.  

### Distance and Value Added  

Geographic distance is not related to value added in the pooled European sample or in any of its subsamples. Distance marginally dampens value added in the United States.  

### Value Added by Country within Europe  

The significant negative coefficient in column 4 for France (FR) indicates that when compared with the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. VCs in France add significantly less value to their ventures. As was the case with face-to-face interaction. these results indicate that country holds significant cxplanatory power for value added in Europe. An inspection of Table 3 shows that VCs in the United Kingdom offer the greatest value of the three, closely followed by those in the Netherlands and. more distantly. by those in France.  

# DISCUSSION  

This study provides insight into how and when VCs in the United States and Europe vary involvement in their portfolio companies and what the value-added consequences of this variation are. We extend prior work on governance in at least two directions: (1) we examined a broader conceptual framework of governance than previously used, and (2) we developed and tested a model of VC value added. Moreover. by collecting data in four major markets for venture capital, we were able to examine what elements of VC involvement are constant across settings and which ones vary. Thus, our results help to illustrate the nature and effect of variations of VC involvement on a country-by-country basis. Knowledge of differences and similarities in norms and practices rises in importance as competition among high-potential ventures becomes increasingly global.  

Our results show that agency. business risk. and information-processing perspectives are useful in predicting VC monitoring behavior in all four markets. However, the weak results with regard to agency risks suggest that problems of delegation of decision-making authority and managerial opportunism may be adequately handled by the contractual and structural arrangements between VCs and their portfolio companies. As predicted, we found that VCs engaged in greater face-to-face oversight of their investments when ventures faced the uncertainties associated with early stage ventures. when the VCs themselves had less experience as VCs. and when the VCs were in greater geographic proximity to the venture. Contrary to expectations, VCs with greater experience in the venture's industry interacted more frequently with their CEOs, and, in Europe, VCs interacted more frequently with CEOs who had greater start-up experience. Poor venture performance did not appear to prompt greater monitoring as had been expected.  

We developed a model of value added based on the expectation that VCs would add most value when ventures were relatively weak. when uncertainty was high. and when VCs were relatively more experienced. Results indicated that, as expected, VCs experienced in the focal industry provided significantly more value than those with less focal industry experience. However, contrary to expectations. VCs added more value to high performing than to poorly performing ventures. Additionally, experience in the venture capital industry was positively (but not significantly) related to value added in the United States but was negatively related to value added in Europe.  

Multiple explanations appear feasible for results contrary to expectations. Our failure to observe the expected relationships between CEO experience and monitoring or value added may have to do with individual preferences or power. Barney et al. (1994a) found inexperienced CEOs more receptive to VC advice. It is possible. therefore, that VCs have to expend greater effort influencing experienced CEOs. A second possibility is that more experienced CEOs demand more attention, especially in Europe where such effort on the part of VCs appears lower. This possibility points up a potential weakness of the agency  

perspective in its implicit assumption that the principal controls the nature and level of gov.   
ernance.  

Perhaps the most fascinating results involve venture performance. We had argued that VCs would interact with and add more value to ventures doing poorly. Our results show that venture performance had no impact on face-to-face interaction, except in the Netherlands where the relationship is positive rather than negative. Further, venture performance was positively related to value added in both the pooled European sample and in the United States. Although business risk arguments suggest that VCs will be more involved when venture viability is threatened, an alternative view is suggested by prospect theory. In this view. decision-makers seek to avoid or limit risks when faced with a situation in which high returns are expected (Sitkin and Pablo 1992). Thus. it may be that when VCs begin to anticipate high returns from superior ventures, they do whatever they can to enhance and protect those returns—i.e., they pour more effort into adding value. This interpretation is consistent with Sapienza et al. (1994) who speculated that VCs might follow a "home run" strategy and focus attention on the winners in their portfolios rather than ventures that are expected to yield little return. Additionally. VCs may seek to add value to high performers because they prefer to be associated with a winner. On the other hand, we cannot rule out the possibility that when VCs are satisfied with venture performance they assume their input has been more worthwhile. Finally, we may simply have the direction of causality reversed. Perhaps when VCs add more value, the ventures do better.  

Differences in our regression equations by country indicate that VCs were driven by different factors in different markets. Further, the significant coefficients for the country variables in the European analyses demonstrate that the level of monitoring and value added of VCs is at significantly different levels in the three countries. Clearly. VCs in France are least involved and add the least value to their portfolio companies: generally speaking, VCs in the United Kingdom are most involved and add the most value. Whereas comparisons between Europe and the United States must be made with caution for reasons explained in the Method section, indications are that VC behavior in the United Kingdom is more similar to that in the United States than are the other two. The numerous similarities across markets are captured by our theoretical perspectives and detailed above. but the substantial differences are consistent with Hofstede's (1984) view that culture plays a dramatic role in the conduct of business. Further. the fact that our models best predicted the behavior of VCs in the United States lends some support to Hofstede's contention that theories are culturally bound: the theories we used were largely developed in the United States.  

A close inspection of the regression equations suggests that VCs in France behave least like those elsewhere. Not only are the French VCs least involved, but their monitoring pattern is hardly captured by the variables measured here. and they are the only country in which value added is perceived as being higher for later stage ventures. One explanation of these differences is that VCFs in France are dominated by financial institutions whose VCs may be primarily former bank managers with less experience in venture building. Another factor may be that institutional investing in France is provided by investors from outside France. Whereas we can only speculate about possible cultural effects on behavior, the fact that VCs in France were least like that of the others is consistent with Hampden-Turner and Trompenaars (1993. p. 15) who place the values of managers in the United States. the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands in one group and those in France, Japan, and Germany in another.  

The most consistent result across the sample was that VCs saw their strategic roles as their most important contributions, followed by their interpersonal roles, and then their networking roles. This result is particularly notable. because so little attention has been given in the literature to the importance of the interpersonal aspects of the venture capital process (Fried and Hisrich 1995). The importance VCs accord to mentor and confidant roles provides additional insight into how VCs develop the desired receptivity in entrepreneurs (Barney et al. 1994a) and are thereby able to add value. One of the VCs we interviewed expressed the importance in this way:  

In some cases, where the relationship is really a solid one with management, we can add a lot more [than just money]. In those cases where we don't have a good relationship--when we don't have rapport—there is just nothing we can do.  

Anecdotal and empirical evidence (Sapienza 1989) suggest that by and large VCs are able to create and maintain the level of understanding and rapport necessary to function effectively. The evidence here suggests that those VCs who develop only distant or adversarial relationships may be seen as uncaring "vulture capitalists" and may not be allowed to perform their fiduciary and advisory duties effectively.  

## Implications for Practice  

Our data support Bhide's (1994) contention that the personal contact of outside investors with the management of private firms plays a role in the governance of those firms, and Fiet's (1995) view that VCs try to manage agency risks through face-to-face post-investment interaction. In our sample, the more developed the venture capital market, the more personally involved VCs were in their investment companies. Further, the more involved they were. the more they contributed to these firms. These observations hold implications for all VCFs. but the implications vary by country in some instances.  

Our results suggest that the high contact level for VCFs in the United States may help to protect the U.S. market somewhat from entry by foreign VCFs. However. given the growing variety of sources of financing in the United States (Timmons and Sapienza 1992). such barriers may not be sufficient to stave off competition. VCFs in the United States may be increasingly pressed to seek other ways to differentiate themselves from domestic competitors and substitutes. The importance accorded VCs interpersonal roles suggests that VCFs might build sustainable competitive advantage by selecting and developing new partners with skills and aptitudes especially suited to the strategic and human challenges faced by entrepreneurs. Our data also suggest that experienced VCs are more effcient in monitoring new ventures; however. value added appears to be most related to focal industry experience. Thus, VCFs should not expect new partners to be as efficient in these roles as they will eventually become. Of course. VC's must also learn to manage the balance between maintaining fiduciary objectivity and establishing a professional closeness. Further, it may be important for VCFs to specialize by industry or to bring in staff to supplement industry-specific knowledge.  

Whereas these same implications exist for VCFs in the United Kingdom, some additional possibilities also exist. First. VCFs in the United Kingdom may be able to more fully penetrate the market for value-added money and assistance. As McNally (1994) points out. the contribution of the venture capital industry to the growth of new firms in the United Kingdom has been somewhat limited by its focus on MBO deals. By partnering with corporate investors who could add their technical expertise to the VCFs strategic and development skils, VCFs could expand into more early stage, high technology investment opportunities. Further, the relative absence of high value-added activity by VCFs on the continent suggests that U.K. VCFs could successfully penetrate that market. Geographic distance will be less an impediment for U.K. than for U.S. VCFs. Nonetheless, new entrants from either country would have to find ways of dealing with barriers posed by language and cultural differences.  

As markets become more fully global, VCFs on the continent may be forced to contend with greater outside competition. Entrepreneurs in the Netherlands and France may be in a position to demand more than mere financial involvement for a stake in their ventures. Even if such competition from the outside does not materialize, VCFs within these countries may gain significant advantage from adopting the practices of U.S. and U.K. VCFs. A question we cannot answer from our data is whether the tremendous emphasis French VCs put on their financial role is consonant with the wishes of their entrepreneurs. Previous studies (e.g., Fredriksen et al. 1990: Landstrom 1991) suggest that entrepreneurs in parts of Europe are dissatisfied with the industry and operating experience of VCs and with their relatively low level of involvement in the venture building process. Whereas such competencies may routinely develop as these markets mature. those VCFs that pioneer this direction in investor activity may reap significant experience and reputational benefits.  

Another implication of our findings is that entrepreneurs may be able to understand and anticipate the variation in their investors\* oversight activities as well as the types of roles VCs see as most critical. Our data reveal that entrepreneurs can expect (1) more involvement when the venture is in an early stage of development: (2) more involvement when the venture is doing well; and (3) more value placed by VCs on their strategic and interpersonal roles than on their roles as contacts to outside networks. As venture capitalists do, entrepreneurs should put effort into selecting investment partners, and after selection, into developing productive exchange relationships with them.  

The absence in this study of an association between value added and the CEO's experience is consistent with our earlier study in the United States (Sapienza 1992) and suggests that VCFs can add value regardless of the experience level of entrepreneurs. The assumption in the United States that experienced entrepreneurs cannot use assistance (Sapienza et al. 1994) is not shared by European venture capitalists who are more involved with experienced CEOs. The actual transfer of knowledge, however, may depend largely on entrepreneurs remaining receptive to advice and information exchange (Barney et al. 1994a).  

This study also holds implications for policy-makers in all four countries. One implication is that if policy-makers are going to try to stimulate growth through venture capital, incentives should be aimed at stimulating more early stage venture capital where the greatest bang for the buck appears to be achieved. If entrepreneurial companies are truly the engines of economic growth and of the renewal of the industrial fber, then policy-makers should direct special attention to providing incentives for VCFs' investment in early stage ventures. In the light of our findings, the recent decision by the Dutch government to discontinue its state guarantee scheme (the so-called PPM rule. in which a portion of losses incurred by VCFs can be recovered) appears to be counterproductive. As a direct consequence of this policy change, many PPM VC funds have ceased operations. diminishing the amount of capital available for start-ups and the supply of experienced VCs. Our results suggest that. instead, the guarantee scheme should have been broadened to also encourage investment in start-ups in other European countries (e.g.. France) where VC involvement is minimal and early stage capital is unavailable.  

Policy-makers might be well advised to provide incentives for managers with industrial experience to start or join VCFs and to assist in the training of recruits from the industrial sectors. Since much of the additional value of venture capital financing appears to come from the interpersonal relations themselves, training should include information not only about the economic aspects of venture building but also about critical social and supportive roles. Finally. agencies could help entrepreneurs by establishing services that provide information on VCFs' investmcnt preferences, performance, cxperience. and reputation. In countries where VCFs follow passive invcstment strategies. policy-makers might also consider legislation reducing impediments to cross-border venture capital investing.  

## Limitations and Future Research Directions  

We urge the reader to view the comparisons of the United States and European markets with extreme caution. As we stated earlier. thc separation in time of the two surveys may have caused unmeasured differences in results. Further, certain limitations exist with regard to all multiple country studies. Apart from the language difficulties, these studies have to acknowledge the differences in definitions and concepts that are used in different cultural settings. Such problems exist whether investigators are using primary or secondary data sources. Researchers would be well advised to seek to introduce variables to control for cultural differences, to include cross-country experts on their research teams. and to design into their instruments mcasures that counter existing differences in terminology or concepts. In essence, when conducting multiple country studies. knowledge of the different institutional and cultural environments is imperative to allow for a meaningful interpretation of the results.  

This study was limited by its cross-scctional design and the self-report nature of the data. Although other or additional sources would have reduced concerns about common method variance. the nature of many of the variables precluded alternative data sources. Nonetheless. where possible, future research may profitably cmploy additional data sources and measures of some of the variables. Our study could not include all variables of possible consequence. For example. we did not measure the possible moderating effects of syndication. Another important variable might be VCF typc. One might speculate that governmentsupported VCFs are hamstrung in their ability to attract high quality VCs. because they are not able to compensate VCs on a level equal to that of private VCFs. We were not able to test this possiblity given the small number of government VC firms in our sample.  

A more complete understanding of investor governance and involvement might be achicved by examining how VCs and entrepreneurs use structural and behavioral factors to define their relationships. Several studies have examined how VCFs adjust governance mechanisms to cope with increased agency. business, or uncertainty risks (e.g.. Barney et al. 1989. 1994a, 1994b: Lerner 1995: Sapienza and Gupta 1994). but it remains a challenge of theoretical and practical importance to examine whether structural and behavioral mechanisms are used to complement or substitute for one another. In terms of the specific roles or activities undertaken by VCs, past studies have focused on the strategic and operational activities of VCs (e.g.. Barney et al. 1994a: Harrison and Mason 1992: MacMillan et al. 1989). The results of this study suggest that deeper investigation into the importance and formation of interpersonal roles and their impact on monitoring effectiveness, entrepreneurial receptivity, and VC value added might also be productive.  

Second, VC involvement behavior might also be more fully explained and predicted by approaching the issues from new perspectives. For example, one route might be to examine VCs as agents in addition to considering their positions as principals. VCs act as the agents of entrepreneurs in negotiating additional financing, selling the venture off to private interests, and taking ventures public. Further, VCs are agents of their limited partners. Bygrave and Shulman (1988) noted that VCFs receive annual fees based on the amount of capital under management. This scheme provides them with an incentive to raise as large a fund as possible. regardless of whether they can adequately perform their fiduciary responsibilities over a greater number of ventures. This scheme also provides them an incentive to invest in later stage ventures since fewer such investments would be required to place all of their capital. As one VC said to us. "It doesn't take a genius to figure out that a $5\%$ return on $\$100$ million is better than $20\%$ on $\$10$ million." Interviews also revealed that conflict of interest is often between one investor and another investor (rather than between investors and management as is assumed by agency theory) because of different preferences in the timing of exit or valuation of the venture. In short, both agency theory and understanding of investor-investee relations might be advanced by relaxing the unidirectional assumptions inherent in current applications of the theory.  

Third. more research is needed on the impact of entrepreneur-investor dynamics on the effectiveness of the board of directors. Information theory and interactional justice theory might be used to help reveal how board meetings may be effectively managed, what information is most critical. and what interactional processes best transfer knowledge and capture the value-adding potential of outside board members. Further. research is needed to investigate the impact of entrepreneur-investor dynamics on venture strategy, including the level of aggressiveness, the level of innovation pursued, and the degree of risk-taking assumed by the venture.  

Finally, the growing phenomenon of cross-border investing offers an attractive arena for study. How do geographic distance. venture stage, language, and cultural factors impact the nature and value of venture capital across borders? Our framework for value added suggests that a complementarity of background would enhance value added. Does a complementarity of cultural perspective also enhance value-adding potential? If a high-potential venture aims to be internationalized from the outset, would it benefit from a board of advisors/investors representing the various regions it is targeting? Although questions of governance and value added are essentially the same for cross-border relations as they are for single country ones. finding the answers may require additional methodological complexity and additional theoretical perspectives to the ones we have applied in the past.
