# Big Data Analytics for Venture Capital Application : Towards Innovation Performance Improvement  

Wenqi Suna, Yuanjun Zhaob,\*, Lu Sun  

College of Economics and Management,Northeast Agricultural University,Harbin150040,China GloriousSunSchool ofBusiness andManagement, Donghua University,Shanghai 200051,China SchoolofCultural Industries andTourism,XiamenUniversityofTechnology,Xiamen361024,Chin  

# ARTICLEINFO  

# ABSTRACT  

Keywords:   
Data panel model   
Big data   
Innovation performance  

By using the panel date of Chinese enterprises, this paper analyzes the influence of venture capital on innovation performance. In this paper, the number of patent application and the patent quality(invention patent applications, number of effective patents, IPC number of international patent classification, and patent claims) are used to measure the innovation performance of enterprises, and the regression results show that the innovation performance is significantly promoted by the venture capital; for industries with higher dependence on external financing and high technology intensity and areas with better protection of property rights, venture capital promotes innovation performance more significantly. In this paper, it further distinguishes the characteristics of venture capital institutions, and finds that the promotion effect of non-state-owned venture capital on innovation performance is significantly greater than that of state-owned venture capital; the venture capital institutions with high reputation and high network capital play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

## 1. Introduction  

Innovation is one of the most important driving forces for sustained economic growth. China is at a critical moment of industrial structure transformation, and the $18^{\mathrm{th}}$ National Congress of the Party clearly put forward that the innovation driven development strategy “must be placed in the core position of the overall development of the country. International experience shows that establishing an effective venture capital mechanism to effectively mobilize venture capital and promote industrialization of scientific and technological achievements is an important link in implementing the innovation strategy. According to Development report of China's Venture Capital Industry in 2017,by the end of 2017, the number of venture capital enterprises registered in China had reached 3546 with total assets of 594.8 billion Yuan and a cumulative investment of 55,478 enterprises. In recent years, about $40\%$ of the listed enterprises in the GEM and SME have venture capital backgrounds. Venture capital supported enterprises are mostly belongs to the strategic industries encouraged by the state, and are important forces to transform the economic structure.  

Through the panel data of enterprises, it analyzes the differences of the characteristics of different industries, regions and venture capital institutions. It uses international patent applications and the patent quality to measure innovation performance, which is a strong evidence to show that the venture capital significantly promotes innovation performance. For industries with higher dependence on external financing and high technology intensity and areas with better protection of property rights, venture capital promotes innovation performance more significantly. The promotion effect of non-state-owned venture capital on innovation performance is significantly greater than that of state-owned venture capital. The venture capital institutions with high reputation and high network capital play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

The contributions of this paper are as follows. Firstly, venture capital is crucial to innovation and economic development. The maturity of capital markets varies from country to country, and so far, there is no empirical study to examine the influence of venture capital on innovation performance in the context of China's transition economy. The individual studies (Popov & Roosenboom, 2013) examined innovation investment only, and did not focus on the innovation performance with economic significance. This paper will make up for the above shortcomings. In particular, the development disparity of China's industries and regions is very large, which provides an ideal research space for this paper. From the perspectives of external financing dependence, high technology intensity and regional protection of property rights in the industry, it provides evidence for venture capital to promote the innovation performance of enterprises. Secondly, state-owned venture capital is a hot issue in recent years (Schertler & Tykvova, 2011). At different development stages of venture capital industry, the role of the government is not the same, and the existing literature has a very limited understanding on its investment mechanism. Thirdly, the economic system is made up of micro subjects. More and more studies are concerned about the formation and effect of relational networks. Venture capital institutions form networks through cooperative investment, and the reputation and network capital of venture capital become important factors influencing its behaviors (Grant & Yeo, 2018). The marketization degree of emerging economies is poor, and reputation and network capital have more room to play. Fourthly, the data of innovation performance with high quality collected and collated in this paper is a breakthrough. Through complex computer programs and a lot of manual work, it collects the data of 8,888, 456 invention patent applications and 7,543,543 patent applications of utility model firstly examined and published by the State Intellectual Property Office before the end of 2017, and through Google Patent, it collects 25,763,487 legal status change data of these patents before the end of December 2017, and the patent applicants are matched with the names of enterprises to form the samples.  

The rest of this paper is arranged as follows: the second part carries out theoretical analysis and puts forward 5 research hypotheses; the third part introduces the research design and describes the data; the fourth part is empirical analysis and robustness test; the fifth part summarizes the full text.  

## 2. Theoretical analysis and research hypothesis  

### 2.1. Venture capital and innovation performance  

Researches find that venture capital is positive correlated with innovation performance in development countries (von Briel, Recker, & Davidsson, 2018), but the researches are not sufficient and the causal relationship is not clear, and there is no relevant research in China. The institutional environment of China is quite different from that of developed countries, and it is necessary to explore the mechanism of venture capital on innovation performance in China.  

Compared with other traditional ways of investment and financing, venture capital can stimulate and promote innovation more for the following reasons: firstly, as an effective equity financing method, venture capital focuses on the long-term investment of early small and medium-sized enterprises, which can effectively reduce the R&D underinvestment of enterprises with strong financing constraints (Kayas, Mclean, Hines, & Wright, 2008), reduce external financing costs, and promotes innovation performance (Rosenbusch, Brinckmann, & Miller, 2013). The screening and supervising ability of venture capital institutions is stronger than that of banks, and the valuation of enterprises is more accurate. In the innovation activities with serious information asymmetry, venture capital in the form of equity can play a better advantage than debt, and can improve the efficiency of resource allocation and the innovative efficiency of innovative enterprises (Nahata, 2008). Secondly, to provide professional value-added services for enterprises, venture capital enters into the board of directors to supervise enterprises (Hochberg, Lindsey, & Westerfield, 2015; Luukkonen, Deschryvere, & Bertoni, 2013). Based on the above analysis, the hypothesis H1 is put forward as:  

H1. Venture capital will promote the innovation performance of enterprises.  

On the basis of hypothesis 1, the following 4 hypotheses are further developed.  

### 2.2. Influence of industrial and regional characteristics  

1 Industrial characteristics: external financing dependence and high technology intensity  

The theoretical analysis of H1 emphasizes that the equity form of venture capital can ease the external financing constraints of enterprises, and venture capital is more likely to invest the innovative technology industry. On this basis, the hypothesis H2 is developed.  

Equity capital can overcome information asymmetry, reduce external financing costs, ease financing constraints, and promote innovation performance. Pierrakis and Saridakis (2017) indicated that for industries with high dependence on external financing, the size of equity market can promote innovation performance, while the size of debt market has a significant negative effect. Startup enterprises with less tangible collateral have greater debt financing constraints, but increasing equity financing won't increase financial risks (Ewens, Nanda, & Rhodes-Kropf, 2018). Equity financing can overcome the problem of information asymmetry and agency more. When the capital market can effectively disperse risks, equity investors are more willing to invest innovative enterprises with high risks, helping to reduce the financing constraints of such enterprises and improve innovation performance (Dai, Jo, & Kassicieh, 2012). Accordingly, the hypothesis H2 is put forward:  

H2. For industries with higher dependence on external financing, venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting innovation performance; for industries with higher concentration of high technology, venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

### 2 Regional characteristics: protection degree of property rights  

The theoretical analysis of Hl emphasizes that venture capital is more likely to invest high-tech industries, and such enterprises have intensive R&D activities and need more legal protections on innovation results. On this basis, the hypothesis H3 is developed. Due to the market failure and spillover effect of innovation, the high-tech industry is facing a particularly serious risk of being occupied in the absence of good legal protection. A large number of researches have shown that property rights protection and law enforcement can effectively improve the investment and financing willingness and R&D efficiency (Andrieu & Staglian0, 2016; Hasan, Khurshed, Mohamed, & Wang, 2018). Based on the above analysis, the hypothesis H3 is put forward:  

H3. In the areas with better protection degree of property rights, venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

### 2.3. Ownership nature of venture capital institutions  

The theoretical analysis of H1 emphasizes the initiative and professionalization of venture capital, and the ownership nature of venture capital institutions greatly affects their initiative and professionalization. On this basis, the hypothesis H4 is developed to further compare the differences between the state-owned and non-state-owned venture capital institutions on innovation performance.  

The agency problems arising from state ownership may weaken its promotion of innovation, for their staff is less professional and it is more difficult to carry out effective incentives inside (Kshetri, 2016); stateowned venture capital institutions have obvious political objectives and cannot easily interfere with corporate governance (Buchner, Mohamed, & Schwienbacher, 2017). However, state-owned capital may also promote innovation more than non-state-owned capital. Firstly, the government involving in the emerging industries as an investor can significantly reduce the financing constraints and the insufficient R&D investment of SMEs (Barry & Mihov, 2015), and enhance their innovation performance. The venture capital supported enterprises with government background also have higher long-term growth (Kwok, Sharma, Singh Gaur, & Ueno, 2018). Secondly, state-owned venture capital institutions have a nature political relationship, so they have more opportunities to promote enterprises to improve innovation per formance. Accordingly, the research hypothesis H4 with competitiveness isproposed:  

H4a. Compared with state-owned venture capital institutions, nonstate-owned venture capital institutions play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

H4b. Compared with state-owned venture capital institutions, the nonstate-owned venture capital institutions have less promotive effect on innovation performance.  

### 2.4. Reputation and network capital of venture capital institutions  

The theoretical analysis of H1 emphasizes the human capital and value-added services of venture capital institutions. On this basis, the hypothesis H5 is developed. Venture capital with high reputation can provide more professional value-added services, and attract underwriters with high reputation and follow-up financing for enterprises through the certification effect; reputation damage is bad for venture capital institutions, for example, it is harder to raise capital in the future, and harder to get high exit returns (Lee, 2017). Therefore, venture capital institutions with high reputation have more motivations to maintain their reputations and provide value-added services, so as to improve the innovation performance of enterprises. Venture capital institutions with high network capital have the advantages of information and social networks, which can better coordinate venture capital institutions, and easier form joint venture capital with other institutions. Based on the above analysis, the hypothesis H5 is put forward:  

H5. Venture capital institutions with high reputation play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance; venture capital with high network capital play a more significant role in promoting innovationperformance.  

## 3. Research design, variables and samples  

### 3.1. Research design  

This paper examines the above five hypotheses through panel data at the enterprise level. The empirical model to test hypothesis H1 is:  

$$
I n n o v a t i o n_{j,t}=\gamma_{0}+\gamma_{1}V C_{j}+\gamma_{2}P o s t_{t}+\gamma_{3}V C_{j}\mathrm{}^{*}P o s t_{t}+C O N T R O L S_{j,t}+\mu_{j,t}
$$  

Among them, $j$ represents the enterprise; $t$ represents the year; $V C$ represents whether venture capital supported enterprises; Post represents whether the year is between the original matching enterprise's venture capital entry and exit. The definition of control variables is shown in Table 1. The multiplication item $V C^{*}P o s t$ reflects the second difference between the changes in innovation performance of venture capital supported enterprises after receiving venture capital support and the changes in innovation performance of non-venture capital supported enterprises during the same period, H1 tests the significance of the multiplication item $V C^{*}P o s t$ coefficient.  

For the test of hypothesis H2, this paper subdivides the sample into high sub-samples and low sub-samples according to the external financing dependence or industrial high-tech intensity of the industry, and carries out model (1) regression on the sub-samples. Referring to Lahr and Mina (2016), it adopted the data of listed companies to calculate the external financing dependence and high-tech intensity of the industry. The calculation method of external financing dependence of industry is as follows: 1) take each listed enterprise's capital expenditure plus R&D expenditure minus the cash flow of operating activities, divide by the sum of capital expenditure and R&D expenditure, and obtain the external financing dependence of each enterprise; 2) take the median of the external financing dependence of all enterprises in the industry for the year; 3) take the median of each industry in the time series of 2007-2015, and get the external financing dependence of the industry. The calculation method of high-tech intensity of the industry is similar, in which the high-tech intensity is measured by the annual growth rate of R&D expenditure. For the external financing dependence of the industry higher than the corporate observation value of the median in total samples, they are the high sub-samples of external financing dependence, and others are low sub-samples of external financing dependence; for the high-tech intensity of the industry higher than the corporate observation value of the median in total samples, they are high sub-samples of high-tech intensity, and others are low sub-samples of high-tech intensity. For the test of hypothesis H3, this paper divides the samples into good sub-samples and bad subsamples according to the degree of regional property rights protection, carries out model (1) regression on the sub-samples. In this paper, the degree of regional property rights protection is measured by the marketization index of the province where the invested enterprise is located. The hypothesis H4's test model is (2):  

$$
\begin{array}{c}{{I n n o v a t i o n_{j,t}=\varphi_{0}+\varphi_{1}G V C_{j}+\varphi_{2}N o n-G V C_{j}+\varphi_{3}P o s t_{t}+\varphi_{4}G V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}}}\ {{+\varphi_{5}N o n-G V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}+C O N T R O L S_{j,t}+\nu_{j,t}}}\end{array}\qquad(\mathrm{~;~}{\begin{array}{c}{{1}}\ {{2}}\ {{3}}\end{array}})
$$  

GVCand $N o n-G V C$ respectively indicate whether the enterprise is supported by state-owned venture capital institutions and whether it is supported by non-state-owned venture capital institutions; Post and CONTROLS are the same as in model (1). Model (2) examines the significance of the coefficients of the two multiplication items respectively.  

The models to test the hypothesis H5 are (3) and (4):  

$$
\begin{array}{r}{I n n o v a t i o n_{j,t}=\varphi_{0}+\varphi_{1}H R a n k V C_{j}+\varphi_{2}L R a n k V C_{j}+\varphi_{3}P o s t_{t}\qquad}\ {+\varphi_{4}H R a n k V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}+\varphi_{5}L R a n k V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}+C O N T R O L S_{j,t}}\ {+\nu_{j,t}\qquad(3)}\end{array}
$$  

$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{I n n o v a t i o n_{j,t}=\varphi_{0}+\varphi_{1}H N e t V C_{j}+\varphi_{2}H N e t V C_{j}+\varphi_{3}P o s t_{t}}\ &{\mathrm{~~}+\varphi_{4}H N e t V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}+\varphi_{5}L N e t V C_{j}^{*}P o s t_{t}+C O N T R O L S_{j,t}}\ &{\mathrm{~~}+\nu_{j,t}}\end{array}
$$  

HRankVC and LRankVC respectively represent whether the enterprise is supported by the venture capital institution with high reputation and whether it is supported by the venture capital institution with low reputation; HNetVC and HNetVC respectively represent whether the enterprise is supported by the venture capital institution with high network capital and whether it is supported by the venture capital institution with low network capital; Post and CONTROLS are the same as in Model (1). Model (3) and (4) respectively test the significance of the multiplication item coefficient. In this paper, the reputation of a venture capital institution is measured by the number of its investment enterprises successfully listed in the past, and the network capital of a venture capital institution is measured by the number of venture capital institutions that have cooperated with during the previous 5 years.  

### 3.2.Measurement ofinnovation performance  

Referring to the existing literature, this paper measures the innovation performance (Innovation) by five indicators such as the number of patents and patent quality.  

#### 1 Number of patents

In this paper, it measures the number of patents (Patent) by the application number of invention patents and utility model patents (Tong and Frame, 1994).  

#### 2 Patent quality  

(1) Invention patents are the most innovative and valuable. In this paper, the application number of invention patents (Invention) is used as the first indicator to measure the patent quality. (2) Patents with low quality are more likely to expire before the specified protection period. During the effective protection period, patents have higher value (Lahr & Mina, 2016). In this paper, valid number of patents (Valid) is used as the second indicator to measure the patent quality. (3) The more international patent classifications (IPC) indicate the wider the technical field in which patents can be applied, and the higher the potential value (Ewens et al., 2018). This paper uses the patent number of IPC $(I P C s)$ as the third indicator to measure the patent quality. (4) The greater the number of claims indicates the more patent rights and the higher the value can be created (Obrimah, 2016). In this paper, the number of patent claims is used as the fourth indicator to measure the patent quality.  

### 3.3. Data source and sample description  

The venture capital data and non-venture capital supported enterprise date referred in this paper are all from the CVSource database, the patent application data comes from the State Intellectual Property Office, and the patent quoted data and legal status date are from Google Patent.  

In this paper, for the 892 companies firstly supported by venture capital in 2010-2017, PSM matching is carried out according to the year, province, industry and application numbers of patents one year before receiving the venture capital, and up to 10 non-venture capital supported enterprises are obtained as control samples. The observation interval is from the first two years before venture capital entered to the exit of venture capital for each venture capital supported enterprise and its matching enterprise. The research sample of this paper is formed by matching the applicants of each patent with the sample enterprise name. Eliminating the observed value of missing control variables, a total of 8765 enterprise-annual observed values in 2010-2017.  

Due to venture capital institutions may choose enterprises with better innovation performance beforehand, referring to the practice of Bengtsson and Hsu (2015) in controlling performance beforehand when matching, this paper controls the enterprise's number of patent applications one year before receiving the venture capital, and reduces the innovation differences of experimental group and control group beforehand. The t-test shows that there is no significant difference in the innovation performance of venture capital supported enterprises and non-venture capital supported enterprises one year before receiving the first round of venture capital (t value $=0.039\mathrm{.}$  

Descriptive statistics of the variables are shown in Table 1. There are no serious multicollinearity problems between regression variables.  

## 4. Empirical analysis  

### 4.1. Venture capital and innovation performance  

Table 2 reports the test of hypothesis H1. The explained variables in column (1) are number of patents (Patent), and the explained variables form column (2) to column (5) are 4 indicators of patents’ quality respectively, and the explaining variable is $V C^{*}P o s t$ .Theresults show that the 5 measured variables of $V C^{*}P o s t$ on innovation performance are significantly positive at $1\%$ , indicating that after the entry of venture capital, the innovation performance improvement of enterprises supported by venture capital is significantly higher than that of enterprises not supported by venture capital. The economic significance is also very significant. The regression results of control variables are basically the same as expected.

### 4.2. Influence of industrial and regional characteristics  

1 Industrial characteristics: external financing dependence and hightech intensity  

Table 3 reports the test results of hypothesis H2. Panel A finds that for the sub-samples with high dependence on external financing, the five measured variables of $V C^{*}P o s t$ on innovation performance are significantly positive at $1\%$ , and the economic significance is also very significant; while for the sub-samples with low dependence on external financing, the five measured variables of $V C^{*}P o s t$ on innovation performance are not significant. The results of Panel B are similar.  

2 Regional characteristics: protection of property rights  

Table 4 reports the test results of hypothesis H3. Table 4 shows that for the sub-samples with good protection of property rights, the three measured variables of $V C^{*}P o s t$ are significantly positive at $1\%$ ,and the two measured variables are significantly positive at $5\%$ ,and the economic significance is also very significant, while for the sub-samples with bad protection of property rights, $V C^{*}P o s t$ is not significant or weaker, indicating that in the areas with better protection of property rights, venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting the innovation performance of enterprises.  

### 4.3.Influence of venture capital institutions’ownership nature  

The above results show that venture capital effectively promoted the innovation performance of enterprises. In this paper, it further uses model (2) to test the hypothesis H4. Table 5 shows the regression results. The five explained variables of innovation for Non-GVC\*Post are significantly positive at $1\%$ , and the economic significance is also significant, while the regression coefficient of $\mathrm{GVC}^{\ast}\mathrm{Post}$ is not significant or weakly significant, indicating that non-state-owned venture capital plays a more significant role in promoting innovation performance, which is consistent with the existing literature (Cumming, Grilli, & Murtinu, 2014).  

### 4.4. Influence of venture capital institutions'reputation and network capital  

Table 6 reports the test results of hypothesis H5. Panel A shows that HRankVC\*Post has significant positive effects on the five measured variables of innovation performance, which are all significant at $1\%$ level, and the economic significance is also very significant, while the regression coefficient and significance are significantly higher than Post, indicating that venture capital institutions with high reputation play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance. Panel B shows that HNetVC\*Post has very significant positive effects on the five measured variables of innovation performance, which are all significant at $1\%$ , and the economic significance is also very significant, while the regression coefficient of LNetVC\*Post is basically not significant or only slightly significant, indicating that venture capital institutions with high network capital play a more significant role in promoting innovation performance.  

### 4.5.Endogenousness problems and other robustness tests  

#### (1) Endogenousness problems  

The results above show that venture capital significantly promoted innovation performance. In the research design, through PSM matching, it controls the innovation performance of enterprises before venture capital entered, and there is no significant difference beforehand between venture capital supported enterprises and the matching non-venture capital supported enterprises. In this paper, PSM matching and multiplication items are used to estimate quadratic difference, which effectively alleviates the endogenousness problems caused by missing variables and selective bias. The above results are less likely to be caused by the reverse causality (that is, enterprises with better innovation performance are more likely to attract venture capital).

All regressions in this paper control the annual and industrial fixed effects, and the same as below.  

In this paper, Heckman two-stage regression is adopted to reduce endogenousness and control unobservable factors.Venture capital institutions tend to invest enterprises nearby, so there is geographic clustering between the invested enterprises and venture capital institutions (Meglio, Mocciaro, Destri, & Capasso, 2017), and in this paper, the number of venture capital institutions in the province where the invested enterprises firstly obtained the venture capital in the year is selected as a instrumental variable. The number of venture capital institutions where the enterprises located will influence the possibility of venture capital entering, but will not directly influence the innovation activities of enterprises. The first-stage regression shows that the coefficient of instrumental variable is very significant (P value $=0.16\$ and the second-stage regression has little difference from the above results, which is consistent to the conclusion.  

(2) Other robustness tests  

In this paper, it also tries a lot of robustness tests, including: 1. Due to the serious lack of leverage of sample enterprises, the control variables in the original regression are deleted; 2. On the basis of original regression, some regional variables which may affect the innovation performance of enterprises are added, such as the number of high-tech enterprises in the province where the enterprises is located, R&D expenditure, GD, and number of high-end innovative talents (academicians of Yangtze River and academicians of two Academies); 3. The sample interval of venture capital supported enterprises and its matching enterprises is adjusted from three years before venture capital first entry to its exit; 4. The enterprises without any patent applications in the sample interval are removed. Through the above robustness test, the main results of this paper do not change too much.

## 5. Discussion and conclusion  

### 5.1.Summary  

As a kind of investment and financing method that can promote innovation in theory, does venture capital promote the innovation of Chinese enterprises in the empirical? This paper examines the influence of venture capital on innovation performance by taking the panel data of manufacturing industrial enterprises in 2010-2017 as samples (Azaizah, Reychav, Raban, Simon, & McHaney, 2018; Batjargal, 2007; Gaddy, Sivaram, Jones, & Wayman, 2017). The results show that the changes in innovation performance of venture capital supported enterprises are significantly higher than that of non-venture capital supported enterprises during the same period. For industries with higher external financing dependence and higher high-tech intensity and regions with better property rights protection, venture capital promotes the innovation performance of enterprises more significantly (Adomako, Opoku, & Frimpong, 2018; Crain, 2018; Meglio et al., 2017). Further distinguishing the characteristics of venture capital institutions, it is found that the role of non-state-owned venture capital institutions in promoting innovation performance is significantly greater than that of state-owned venture institutions; venture capital institutions with high reputation and high network capital play more significant roles in promoting innovation performance (Benjamin & Delvin, 2018; McDowell, Peake, Coder, & Harris, 2018; Larsen, & Olaisen, 2013) The research conclusions of this paper provide evidence of emerging markets for venture capital to promote innovation performance, and help to understand the differences of innovation performance in different countries. It shows that China's venture capital has effectively promoted innovation performance, and has important reference significance for formulating policies in the development and structural adjustment of venture capital industry (Chemmanur, Hull, & Krishnan, 2016; Futterer, Schmidt, & Heidenreich, 2018; Mamonov & Triantoro, 2018; Meuleman, Jaaskelainen, Maula, & Wright, 2017; Otchere & Vong, 2016; Pradhan et al., 2018; Vergara, Bonilla, & Sepulveda,  2016;Anonymous, 2018; McKenzie,Satchell, & Wongwachara, 2012).  

### 5.2. Contributions to theory  

Currently, due to convenient conditions and procedures, venture capital has become the main financing channel for Chinese enterprises, especially startup enterprises and it has broken through disadvantages of traditionally severe dependence on commercial bank financing. Studying the influence effect and action mechanism of venture capital on enterprise performance is of crucial practical value and important theoretical significance. Regarding the influence of venture capital on the performance of listed companies, there are positive and negative research conclusions in existing literature researches. Theories supporting the positive influence of venture capital on enterprises mainly include “screening supervision theory", and theories supporting the negative influence of venture capital on enterprise performance mainly include “reverse choice theory" and “grandstanding motivation hypothesis". Due to different samples, the influence of venture capital on the performance of listed companies can be reflected in different countries and regions and in different periods to varying degrees. However, China's researches in this aspect is mainly focus on main board and SME board listed companies. The newly established GEM lacks data with few researches, and particularly very few researches involve the post-IPO performance.

Regarding the theoretical significance, analyzing the influence effect of venture capital on enterprise performance, and deeply testing the impact mechanism and acting path of venture capital on enterprise performance can help to clearly reveal the function and internal mechanism of venture capital for enterprise performance, enrich and improve enterprise theory and corporate governance theory. Increasing investment in R&D is conducive to enterprise R&D of new technologies, output of new products, and enterprise overall profitability in the market, which have been confirmed in many scholars' researches. But the risks and lagging earnings of R&D, serious information mismatch have greatly restricted the investment of R&D projects, thus influencing enterprise performance ability, which have also been confirmed by somescholars.  

The theoretical significance of the topic lies in that it can eliminate the attractiveness of enterprises with good performance enterprises to venture capital and further investigate the influence of venture capital on SME performance. Related researches in recent years have affirmed the positive correlation relationship between venture capital and SME performance, but the relationship is bidirectional. The good performance of SMEs may be the result of the influence after venture capital participation, or the result of venture capital deliberately selecting enterprises with good performance. Regarding empirical method selection, this paper adopts propensity score matching method popular in recent years, which can eliminate the attractiveness of SMEs with better performance to venture capital institutions, and analyze the influence of venture capital on SME performance unidirectionally, further understand the role of venture capital, and enrich theories in related fields.  

### 5.3. Implications on practice  

Regarding the practical significance, empirical analysis of the influence of venture capital on enterprise performance is conducive to scientific understanding of the influence of venture capital on performance, analysis of the problems, opportunities and challenges of venture capital in promoting enterprise development. It can provide reasonable suggestions for enterprises to obtain venture capital, promote the benign interaction between venture capital institutions and enterprises, and provide experience references and decision-making support for the government to scientifically manage the venture capital market and facilitate the role of venture capital in enterprise and economic development.  

On the one hand, it can help to improve enterprise performance. With the advent of low-profit era, micro-market individuals try their best to improve performance and obtain profit for self-protection and development in the increasingly complicated market environment. The inimitable innovation ability is an important capital to enhance enterprise competitiveness and to obtain leading position ahead of peers in the market. Generally speaking, innovation capability improvement requires for carrying out supportive activities, that is, the R &D investment at the early stage. Therefore, the measurement of the R& D intensity of a certain enterprise can manifest the level of its innovation capability. The more innovative individuals are, the more likely they are to occupy advantageous position in the market. On the other hand, it is good for guiding the benign development of venture capital institutions and promoting the growth of capital market. As the product of capital market development, venture capital has received people's different judgements. This paper collects relevant data and explores the influence of venture capital on the relationship between R&D input and performance, which can confirm the role of VCs in promoting microindividuals and even the entire market economy. In favor of future development of VC institutions, it can further perfect China's capital market, and arouse entrepreneurs’ attention to VC institutions in practice field at the same time.  

The practical significance of the topic lies in strengthening SME to pay attention to venture capital. With the gradual promotion of domestic mass entrepreneurship and innovation, venture capital has gradually exerted its value. SMEs as the main force of innovation is subject to scale under a lot of restrictions on financing. Participation of venture capital can bring urgent-needed funds to SMEs in the initial stage. Also, venture capital can also assist enterprises in internal management and external market development, thus creating added value to the enterprise. As venture capital began late in China, in addition to the imperfect domestic mechanism, defective laws and regulations, it is not necessarily applicable to study domestic venture capital with reference to foreign researches. This paper can further demonstrate the role of venture capital, and provide references for SMEs to choose whether to cooperate with venture capital and to cooperate with what kind of venture capital institutions. From the macroscopic perspective, due to the immature development of China's venture capital, GEM establishment for only several years, we need to demonstrate whether the influence of China's venture capital on GEM listed companies' performance is positive or not. The research in this paper can also reflect the short-term and long-term operational effects of China's GEM listed companies. From the microcosmic perspective, underfunded small and medium-sized enterprises need to clarify the long-term effects of venture capital on enterprises for selectively choosing venture capital institutions and better cooperation with venture capital institutions. For venture capital, verifying the existence of China's "reverse selection effect" in China is of practical significance. This paper studies the relationship between venture capital, its characteristics and enterprise performance for the purpose of reducing information asymmetry problems for capital market participants to a certain degree, and provide reference information for market stakeholders decision-making. (1) It can help to provide references for venture enterprise financing decisionmaking. By studying the influence of venture capital intervention and venture capital related characteristics on enterprise performance, venture companies can refer to the research results to choose different venture capitals so that venture capital can play an effective promoting role. (2) It helps the venture capital institutions to pay attention to investment effectiveness. Venture capital institutions can refer to relevant research conclusions to choose a more effective and stable investment methods and pay attention to possible problems in the investment process, which can facilitate venture capitalists’ better operation and management of venture capital, and carry out venture capital activities orderly on the basis of guaranteeing venture capitalists' benefits. (3) It can help to the judgment of risk market participants' judge venture business, reduce information asymmetry of capital market participants according to the influence of venture capital intervention, related characteristics, and results of enterprise performance, and help enterprises to make reasonable judgment on the potential of venture business.
